title.text: Schema allows additional properties

description.text:
Description

The schema you have defined allows additional properties, either intentionally or unintentionally.

In JSON, by default, any object can also accept additional properties. OpenAPI Specification (OAS) v2 does not define this behavior, and the current tooling (such as parsers and codegen) does not support it. Instead, they only accept the value object for this property. Thus, it is not recommended to use Boolean values.

However, OAS v2 does support using additionalProperties to specify a schema to which the additional properties must conform.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

schema-object-additionalproperties-true.shortDescription: The schema you have defined allows additional properties, either intentionally or unintentionally.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. In this case, the schema does not use any combining operations (so there is no need to allow additional properties) but additionalProperties is set to true:

code.yaml:
post:
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
          tag:
            type: string
        required:
          - name
        additionalProperties: true

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

If you do not clearly define the schema and you leave properties of a JSON payload empty, you effectively allow attackers to pass in any data. This means that you are opening your backend to various attacks, such as SQL injection.

This also lets attackers to try various unexpected inputs. Unexpected inputs may cause the backend server to crash or behave in an unexpected way. This in turn may cause the server to potentially leak stack trace that can be used for further attacks, or even data.

If no restrictions to the set of properties in the JSON payload are enforced, the API might also accept more fields than expected. The received payloads could be blindly transformed into an object and stored, overwriting sensitive internal data.

Remediation

The safest option is not to allow additional properties. If the schema does not use allOf at all, make sure you define all properties of the accepted JSON payload in the schema itself.

Do not use combining operations (allOf) for defining additional properties in API definitions following the OAS v2.

We recommend updating your API definition to follow the OAS v3, because it offers proper support for additionalProperties as Boolean, in addition to other improvements.

If you cannot update your API to OAS v3, use additionalProperties to provide the schema that you want to support:

code.yaml:
definitions:
  Pet:
    type: object
    properties:
      name:
        type: string
      petType:
        type: string
    required:
      - name
      - petType
    additionalProperties: "#/definitions/Cat"
  Cat:
    properties:
      furType:
        type: enum
        enum:
          - short-haired
          - long-haired
          - curly
          - naked
        default: short-haired

title.text: Schema of a JSON object has no properties defined

description.text:
Description

The schema for a JSON payload does not have any properties defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

schema-object-without-properties.shortDescription: The schema for a JSON payload does not have any properties defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. The method defines the schema as the JSON payload NewPet. However, the actual content of that JSON object is not defined:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    name: pet
    in: body
    description: pet to add to the system
    required: true
    schema:
      $ref: "#/definitions/NewPet"
# ...
NewPet:
  type: object
  description: JSON defining a Pet object

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

If you do not clearly define the schema and you leave properties of a JSON payload empty, you effectively allow attackers to pass in any data. This means that you are opening your backend to various attacks, such as SQL injection.

This also lets attackers to try various unexpected inputs. Unexpected inputs may cause the backend server to crash or behave in an unexpected way. This in turn may cause the server to potentially leak stack trace that can be used for further attacks, or even data.

If no restrictions to the set of properties in the JSON payload are enforced, the API might also accept more fields than expected. The received payloads could be blindly transformed into an object and stored, overwriting sensitive internal data.

Remediation

Make sure you define all properties of the accepted JSON payload to enforce limitations to what the schema accepts.

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    name: pet
    in: body
    description: pet to add to the system
    required: true
    schema:
      $ref: "#/definitions/NewPet"
# ...
NewPet:
  type: object
  required:
    - name
  properties:
    name:
      type: string
      description: Pet name
    tag:
      type: string
      description: Pet tag

title.text: Pattern for string schema is too loose

description.text:
Description

The pattern for a string schema is too loosely defined. It does not actually limit what gets passed to the API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

schema-string-loosepattern.shortDescription: The pattern for a string schema is too loosely defined. It does not actually limit what gets passed to the API.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. The defined pattern is so loose that the API effectively accepts any string of any size and value:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
            pattern: .*

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

If you define too loose pattern for strings, you do not actually limit what is accepted as the input. This could open your backend server to various attacks, like SQL injections or buffer overflows.

Remediation

Set a well-defined regular expression that matches your requirements in the pattern field of string parameters. This ensures that only strings matching the set pattern get passed to your API.

For example, the API below only accepts UUIDs that are compliant with RFC 4122:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
            maxLength: 10
            pattern: ^[0-9a-f]{8}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[1-5][0-9a-f]{3}-[89AB][0-9a-f]{3}-[0-9a-f]{12}$

sections.text:
We recommend that you carefully think what kind of regular expression best matches your needs. Do not simply blindly copy the pattern from the code example.

For more information on regular expressions, see the following:

  • Language-agnostic information on regular expressions at Base Definitions page on regular expressions
  • OWASP Validation Regex Repository
  • RegExr, an online tool for building and testing regular expressions
For examples on some of the common regulars expressions, see the full article.

title.text: String schema has no maximum length defined

description.text:
Description

A string schema does not specify the maximum length for the accepted strings.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

schema-string-maxlength.shortDescription: A string schema does not specify the maximum length for the accepted strings.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

If you do not limit the length of strings, attackers can send longer strings to your API than what your backend server can handle. This could overload your backend server and make it crash. In some cases, this could cause a buffer overflow and allow for executing arbitrary code. Long strings are also more prone to injection attacks.

Remediation

Set the maxLength property in string schemas to ensure that only strings of the expected size get passed to your API:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
            maxLength: 10
            pattern: ^[0-9a-f]{8}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[1-5][0-9a-f]{3}-[89AB][0-9a-f]{3}-[0-9a-f]{12}$

sections.text:
We also recommend that you specify a regular expression to further lock down the expected string format.

For more information on regular expressions, see the following:

  • Language-agnostic information on regular expressions at Base Definitions page on regular expressions
  • OWASP Validation Regex Repository
  • RegExr, an online tool for building and testing regular expressions

For examples on some of the common regulars expressions, see the full article.

title.text: String schema has no pattern defined

description.text:
Description

A string schema does not define any pattern for the accepted strings. This means that it does not limit the values that get passed to the API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

schema-string-pattern.shortDescription: A string schema does not define any pattern for the accepted strings. This means that it does not limit the values that get passed to the API.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. Because no pattern is defined, the API accepts a string of any size and value:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

If you do not define a pattern for strings, no restrictions can be enforced and any string is accepted as the input. This could open your backend server to various attacks, such as SQL injection.

Remediation

Set a well-defined regular expression that matches your requirements in the pattern field of string parameters. This ensures that only strings matching the set pattern get passed to your API.

For example, the API below only accepts UUIDs that are compliant with RFC 4122:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
            maxLength: 10
            pattern: ^[0-9a-f]{8}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[1-5][0-9a-f]{3}-[89AB][0-9a-f]{3}-[0-9a-f]{12}$

sections.text:
We recommend that you carefully think what kind of regular expression best matches your needs. Do not simply blindly copy the pattern from the code example.

For more information on regular expressions, see the following:

  • Language-agnostic information on regular expressions at Base Definitions page on regular expressions
  • OWASP Validation Regex Repository
  • RegExr, an online tool for building and testing regular expressions
For examples on some of the common regulars expressions, see the full article.

title.text: Format of a string schema is unknown

description.text:
Description

The format you have defined for a string schema does not match formats defined in either the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) or JSON Schema Specification. Unknown formats cannot be enforced to protect your API, so it is like you had not defined a format at all.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

schema-string-unknown-format.shortDescription: The format you have defined for a string schema does not match formats defined in either the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) or JSON Schema Specification. Unknown formats cannot be enforced to protect your API, so it is like you had not defined a format at all.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. The format mail for the property userName is unknown and therefore does not restrict the accepted values:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new user
  operationId: addUser
  parameters:
    - name: user
      in: body
      description: User to add
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        required:
          - name
          - userName
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
          userName:
            type: string
            format: mail

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

If you do not define a known format for strings, no restrictions can be enforced and any string is accepted as the input. This could open your backend server to various attacks, such as SQL injection.

Using your internal, company-specific formats is not currently supported.

Remediation

Make sure that you only use known formats for strings. This ensures that only parameters of the expected format get passed to the backend.

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new user
  operationId: addUser
  parameters:
    - name: user
      in: body
      description: User to add
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        required:
          - name
          - userName
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
          userName:
            type: string
            format: email

sections.text: If you want to use your internal, company-specific format, make sure to also use properties like maximum, minimum, pattern, and maxLenght to constrain the accepted values.

title.text: Schema defines combining operations

description.text:
Description

The schema defines combining operations allOf which requires additionalProperties to behave as Boolean.

In JSON, by default, any object can also accept additional properties. OpenAPI Specification (OAS) v2 does not define this behavior, and the current tooling (such as parsers and codegen) does not support it. Instead, they only accept the value object for this property. Thus, it is not recommended to use Boolean values.

However, OAS v2 does support using additionalProperties to specify a schema to which the additional properties must conform.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

schema-xof-additionalproperties-false.shortDescription: The schema defines combining operations allOf which requires additionalProperties to behave as Boolean.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. A reusable schema in the definitions section has been extended with an enum from allOf, and the property additionalProperties is set to trueto allow additional properties:

code.yaml:
definitions:
  Pet:
    type: object
    properties:
      name:
        type: string
      petType:
        type: string
    required:
      - name
      - petType
  Cat:
    type: object
    allOf:
      - $ref: "#/definitions/Cat"
      - type: object
        properties:
          furType:
            type: enum
            enum:
              - short-haired
              - long-haired
              - curly
              - naked
            default: short-haired
    additionalProperties: true

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

While it is unlikely that attackers will be able to directly breach your API because of a boolean value for additionalProperties, it may still pose a risk to API security. Because this is not a documented part of the OAS, the API implementation may not behave according to developer expectations. Such a discrepancy has an inherent risk and is not recommended.

Remediation

Do not use combining operations (allOf) for defining additional properties in API definitions following the OAS v2.

We recommend updating your API definition to follow the OAS v3, because it offers proper support for additionalProperties as Boolean, in addition to other improvements.

If you cannot update your API to OAS v3, use additionalProperties to provide the schema that you want to support:

code.yaml:
definitions:
  Pet:
    type: object
    properties:
      name:
        type: string
      petType:
        type: string
    required:
      - name
      - petType
    additionalProperties: "#/definitions/Cat"
  Cat:
    properties:
      furType:
        type: enum
        enum:
          - short-haired
          - long-haired
          - curly
          - naked
        default: short-haired

title.text: Value of the schema discriminator must be a required property

description.text:
Description

The discriminator property in the schema in question has not been listed as a required property. The value of the discriminator property must be a string.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-discriminator-required.shortDescription: The discriminator property in the schema in question has not been listed as a required property. The value of the discriminator property must be a string.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the discriminator petType is not included in the required properties:

code.yaml:
Pet:
  type: object
  discriminator: petType
  properties:
    name:
      type: string
    petType:
      type: string
  required:
    - name

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all discriminator values are listed as required properties.

code.yaml:
Pet:
  type: object
  discriminator: petType
  properties:
    name:
      type: string
    petType:
      type: string
  required:
    - name
    - petType

title.text: Schema discriminator property must be a string

description.text:
Description

You have defined a discriminator that is not a string. Discriminators must always be of the type string.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-discriminator-string.shortDescription: You have defined a discriminator that is not a string. Discriminators must always be of the type string.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the type of the discriminator age is integer:

code.yaml:
definitions:
  Pet:
    type: object
    discriminator: age
    properties:
      name:
        type: string
      age:
        type: integer
    required:
      - name
      - age

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all discriminator values are strings.

code.yaml:
definitions:
  Pet:
    type: object
    discriminator: age
    properties:
      name:
        type: string
      age:
        type: string
    required:
      - name
      - age

title.text: Schema discriminator property must match a property with the same name

description.text:
Description

The discriminator of the schema in question must match a property with the same name.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-discriminator-value.shortDescription: The discriminator of the schema in question must match a property with the same name.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the discriminator value is animalType but the defined property is actually called petType:

code.yaml:
definitions:
  Pet:
    type: object
    discriminator: animalType
    properties:
      name:
        type: string
      petType:
        type: string
    required:
      - name
      - animalType

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all discriminator values match defined properties.

code.yaml:
definitions:
  Pet:
    type: object
    discriminator: petType
    properties:
      name:
        type: string
      petType:
        type: string
    required:
      - name
      - petType

title.text: Security field references a security scheme not defined in '#/securityDefinitions'

description.text:
Description

A security requirement in the security field contains a reference to a security scheme that is not defined in the API.

The security field specifies what kind of authentication your API requires, either on global level for the whole API or for individual API operations.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-global-securityrequirement-unre.shortDescription: A security requirement in the security field contains a reference to a security scheme that is not defined in the API.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The security field references an OAuth security scheme, but this scheme has not been defined in securityDefinitions:

code.yaml:
schemes:
  - https
# ...
securityDefinitions:
  regularSecurity:
    type: basic
# ...
security:
  regularSecurity: []
  OAuth2:
    - readOnly

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all security schemes that the security field references are defined.

code.yaml:
schemes:
  - https
# ...
securityDefinitions:
  regularSecurity:
    type: basic
  OAuth2:
    type: oauth2
    flow: accessCode
    scopes:
      {}
      # ...
# ...
security:
  regularSecurity: []
  OAuth2:
    - readOnly

title.text: Default value for the header is not consistent with the header's type

description.text:
Description

The default value you have defined for a header is not consistent with the type of the header.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-header-default-invalid.shortDescription: The default value you have defined for a header is not consistent with the type of the header.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The header parameter accepts integer values but the default value is a string.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: OK
    headers:
      x-internal-id:
        type: integer
        default: "0"
        # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all default values for headers match the header type.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: OK
    headers:
      x-internal-id:
        type: integer
        default: 0
        # ...

title.text: Enum value for the header is not consistent with the header's type

description.text:
Description

The enum value you have specified for a header does not match the type of the header.

semantic-header-enum-type-incompatible.shortDescription: The enum value you have specified for a header does not match the type of the header.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all enum values for headers match the type of the header.

title.text: At least one host must be defined

description.text:
Description

You have not defined any hosts in your API definition.

According to the Open API Specification (OAS), the top-level property host is optional and if not present, the host and the port serving the API documentation are used. However, there is no host serving the documentation for the APIs in 42Crunch Platform, so Security Audit cannot infer the host.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-host-undefined.shortDescription: You have not defined any hosts in your API definition.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
swagger: "2.0"
info:
  description: My example API
  version: 1.0.0
  title: My API
paths:
  {}
  # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined at least one host for your API.

code.yaml:
swagger: "2.0"
info:
  description: My example API
  version: 1.0.0
  title: My API
host: my.api.com:8090
paths:
  {}
  # ...

title.text: Default value for the array item is not consistent with the item's type

description.text:
Description

The default value you have defined for an array item is not consistent with the type of the item.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-item-default-invalid.shortDescription: The default value you have defined for an array item is not consistent with the type of the item.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The property count only accepts integer values, but the default value is a string:

code.yaml:
type: array
items:
  type: object
  properties:
    count:
      type: integer
      format: int32
      default: "0"
      # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all default values for array items match the array items' type.

code.yaml:
type: array
items:
  type: object
  properties:
    count:
      type: integer
      format: int32
      default: 0
      # ...

title.text: Enum value for the items of an array is not consistent with the items type

description.text:
Description

The enum value in an array does not match the type your have specified for the items in the array.

semantic-item-enum-type-incompatible.shortDescription: The enum value in an array does not match the type your have specified for the items in the array.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all enum values in arrays match the type defined for the items.

title.text: Operation defines both a body parameter and a 'formData' parameter

description.text:
Description

The operation in question has a body parameter and a formData parameter defined. It can have only one of these two.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-operation-body-formdata.shortDescription: The operation in question has a body parameter and a formData parameter defined. It can have only one of these two.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all operations have only one body parameter orformData parameter defined.

title.text: Example is not consistent with 'mediaType' defined in the operation's 'produces' property

description.text:
Description

The example of the operation in question is not consistent with the MIME type defined in the produces property of the operation.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-operation-example.shortDescription: The example of the operation in question is not consistent with the MIME type defined in the produces property of the operation.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all examples of the operations are consistent with the MIME type defined in the produces property.

title.text: 'OperationId' is not unique throughout the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

The operation does not have a unique operationID. All operations in your API must have unique operation IDs.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-operation-id.shortDescription: The operation does not have a unique operationID. All operations in your API must have unique operation IDs.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all operations in your API have a unique operationID.

title.text: Operation defines multiple body parameters

description.text:
Description

The operation in question defines multiple body parameters. Only one body parameter is allowed.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-operation-multiple-body.shortDescription: The operation in question defines multiple body parameters. Only one body parameter is allowed.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all operations have only one body parameter.

title.text: Security field of the operation references a security scheme not defined in '#/securityDefinitions'

description.text:
Description

A security requirement in the security field contains a reference to a security scheme that is not defined in the API.

The security field specifies what kind of authentication your API requires, either on global level for the whole API or for individual API operations.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-operation-securityrequirement-u.shortDescription: A security requirement in the security field contains a reference to a security scheme that is not defined in the API.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The security field references an OAuth security scheme, but this scheme has not been defined in securityDefinitions:

code.yaml:
schemes:
  - https
# ...
securityDefinitions:
  regularSecurity:
    type: basic
# ...
security:
  regularSecurity: []
  OAuth2:
    - readOnly

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all security schemes that the security field references are defined.

code.yaml:
schemes:
  - https
# ...
securityDefinitions:
  regularSecurity:
    type: basic
  OAuth2:
    type: oauth2
    flow: accessCode
    scopes:
      {}
      # ...
# ...
security:
  regularSecurity: []
  OAuth2:
    - readOnly

title.text: Property 'allowEmptyValue' is only allowed for query parameters

description.text:
Description

The parameter in question has the allowEmptyValue property defined, but it is not a query or a formData parameter. Only query and formData parameters can have the allowEmptyValue property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-parameter-allowemptyvalue.shortDescription: The parameter in question has the allowEmptyValue property defined, but it is not a query or a formData parameter. Only query and formData parameters can have the allowEmptyValue property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The parameter has allowEmptyValue set to true, but in is set to header:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: myAPIparameter
    type: string
    in: header
    required: true
    pattern: ^([a-zA-Z0-9_=]{4,})\.([a-zA-Z0-9_=]{4,})\.([a-zA-Z0-9_\-\+\/=]{4,})$
    maxLength: 700
    allowEmptyValue: true
  # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that only query and formData parameters have the allowEmptyValue property.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: myAPIparameter
    type: string
    in: query
    required: true
    pattern: ^([a-zA-Z0-9_=]{4,})\.([a-zA-Z0-9_=]{4,})\.([a-zA-Z0-9_\-\+\/=]{4,})$
    maxLength: 700
    allowEmptyValue: true
  # ...

title.text: Default value for the parameter is not consistent with the parameter's type

description.text:
Description

The default value you have defined for a parameter is not consistent with the type of the parameter.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-parameter-default-invalid.shortDescription: The default value you have defined for a parameter is not consistent with the type of the parameter.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The parameter type is set to integer, but the default value is a string:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  type: integer
  format: int32
  default: "0"
  description: The total number of results.
  # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all default values for parameters match the parameter type.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  type: integer
  format: int32
  default: 0
  description: The total number of results.
  # ...

title.text: Enum value for the parameter is not consistent with the parameter's type

description.text:
Description

The enum value you have specified for a parameter does not match the parameter type.

semantic-parameter-enum-type-incompatibl.shortDescription: The enum value you have specified for a parameter does not match the parameter type.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all enum values for parameters match the parameter type.

title.text: File parameter is used in an operation where the 'consumes' property does not allow it

description.text:
Description

The parameter file is used in an operation where the consumes property does not allow it. This can happen if you have not defined the consumes property as:

  • multipart/form-data
  • application/x-www-form-urlencoded

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-parameter-file.shortDescription: The parameter file is used in an operation where the consumes property does not allow it. This can happen if you have not defined the consumes property as:

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the consumes property allows using the file parameter, or remove the parameter.

title.text: Parameters have the same name + in combination

description.text:
Description

Two or more parameters have the same nameIn combination (parameter name + in). The nameIn combinations must be unique.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-parameter-namein-multiple.shortDescription: Two or more parameters have the same nameIn combination (parameter name + in). The nameIn combinations must be unique.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all parameters have unique nameIn combinations.

title.text: Header parameters have the same name

description.text:
Description

Two or more header parameters have properties name that are considered equal.

While parameter names normally are case-sensitive, RFC 7230 states that HTTP header names are not. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) does therefore not consider header parameters names as case-sensitive, so names like content-type and Content-Type are considered equal. You should not have equal header parameters in your OpenAPI definition.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-parameter-namein-multiple-heade.shortDescription: Two or more header parameters have properties name that are considered equal.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: Auth-Token
    in: header
    description: Auth-Token
    required: true
    type: string
  - name: auth-token
    in: header
    description: Authorization token for user
    required: true
    type: string

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all header parameters have unique name.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: Auth-Token
    in: header
    description: Auth-Token
    required: true
    type: string
  - name: auth-token
    in: header
    description: Authorization token for user
    required: true
    type: string

title.text: Path parameter in the path has no corresponding path template

description.text:
Description

The path parameter in question does not have a corresponding path template.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-parameter-nopathtemplate.shortDescription: The path parameter in question does not have a corresponding path template.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all path parameters have corresponding path templates, or remove the parameters that do not have them.

title.text: Path template for the path is empty

description.text:
Description

The path template for the path in question is empty and has not been defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-parameter-path-name-empty.shortDescription: The path template for the path in question is empty and has not been defined.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all paths have path templates defined.

title.text: Path template has no corresponding path parameter definition

description.text:
Description

The path in question includes one ore more path parameters that do not have corresponding parameters in the path template.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-parameter-path-undefined.shortDescription: The path in question includes one ore more path parameters that do not have corresponding parameters in the path template.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all path parameters have corresponding parameters in the path templates, or remove the parameters that do not correspond the path template.

title.text: Paths are equivalent

description.text:
Description

Your API contains paths that are equivalent. In practice, these paths are considered to be identical because there is no way of telling them apart.

This can happen, for example, if you have defined same path but with different parameter name for different operations. The parameter name alone does not make the path unique.

The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) states that all paths must be unique.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-path-equivalent.shortDescription: Your API contains paths that are equivalent. In practice, these paths are considered to be identical because there is no way of telling them apart.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. GET and PUT operations have the same path but different parameter:

code.yaml:
paths:
  "/path/{IDs}":
    get:
      description: Get the ID list
      parameters:
        name: IDs
        in: path
        required: true
        type: string
        # ...
  "/path/{addIDs}":
    put:
      description: Add IDs to the ID list
      parameters:
        name: addIDs
        in: path
        required: true
        type: string
        # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Define a single path /path/{parameter} with multiple operations (here GET and PUT):

code.yaml:
"/path/{IDs}":
  get:
    description: Get the ID list
    parameters:
      name: IDs
      in: path
      required: true
      type: string
      # ...
  put:
    description: Add IDs to the ID list
    parameters:
      name: addIDs
      in: path
      required: true
      type: string
      # ...

sections.text: If you need multiple paths, make sure that all paths are considered unique.

title.text: Schema property is not unique throughout 'properties', 'allOf', and 'additionalProperties' fields

description.text:
Description

Two or more schema properties have duplicate keys. Schema properties must have unique keys throughout all properties, allOf, and additionalProperties fields.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-property-duplicate-key.shortDescription: Two or more schema properties have duplicate keys. Schema properties must have unique keys throughout all properties, allOf, and additionalProperties fields.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all schema properties have unique keys.

title.text: Required property is missing

description.text:
Description

Your API is missing one or more properties that the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines as required. If you do not define all required properties, your API definition does not fully conform to the OAS.

The names of objects and properties are case-sensitive, so make sure that you have spelled them correctly.

The following objects themselves are optional, but if defined in the API definition, must have the following properties defined:

Object Required properties
External Documentation url
License name
Response description
Tag name

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-property-required.shortDescription: Your API is missing one or more properties that the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines as required. If you do not define all required properties, your API definition does not fully conform to the OAS.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The license object of this sample API is missing the field name, which is defined as a required property in the OAS:

code.yaml:
license:
  description: This is a sample license.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that your API has all the properties that the OAS requires.

code.yaml:
license:
  name: My Sample License
  description: This is a sample license.

title.text: HTTP status codes in responses must be between 100 and 599

description.text:
Description

One or more responses objects in your API have non-standard HTTP response code keys. The HTTP response code keys must be between 100 and 599.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-response-httpstatus.shortDescription: One or more responses objects in your API have non-standard HTTP response code keys. The HTTP response code keys must be between 100 and 599.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the response code has a typo and is missing one number:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "20":
    description: Expected response to a valid request
    schema:
      $ref: "#/definitions/Pets"

sections.text: Or your response code might be bigger than the maximum defined in the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) Status Code Registry:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "659":
    description: Response to the error XYZ
    schema:
      $ref: "#/definitions/Pets"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all responses objects have HTTP response code keys between 100 and 599.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: Expected response to a valid request
    schema:
      $ref: "#/definitions/Pets"

title.text: Default value for the schema property is not consistent with the property's type

description.text:
Description

The default value you have defined for a schema property is not consistent with the type of the property.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-schema-default-invalid.shortDescription: The default value you have defined for a schema property is not consistent with the type of the property.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all default values for schema properties match the property type.

title.text: Enum value for the schema is not consistent with the schema's type

description.text:
Description

The enum value you have specified for a schema does not match the type of the schema.

semantic-schema-enum-type-incompatible.shortDescription: The enum value you have specified for a schema does not match the type of the schema.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all enum values for schemas match the type of schema.

title.text: Schema does not define a required property

description.text:
Description

One or more properties that you have defined as required are not defined in the schema.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-schema-property-required.shortDescription: One or more properties that you have defined as required are not defined in the schema.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The schema requires the property name, but it has not been defined:

code.yaml:
name: Pet
in: body
description: pet to add to the system
required: true
schema:
  type: object
  additionalProperties: "false"
  required:
    - name
  properties:
    breed:
      type: string
    age:
      type: integer

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties you have defined as required are also defined in the schema.

code.yaml:
name: pet
in: body
description: pet to add to the system
required: true
schema:
  type: object
  additionalProperties: "false"
  required:
    - name
  properties:
    name:
      type: string
    breed:
      type: string
    age:
      type: integer

title.text: Schemes should be defined

description.text:
Description

You have not defined the schemes field in your API.

The Open API Specification (OAS) does not define the schemes field as mandatory and states that when missing, the default scheme is the same as used to access your API definition itself. However, because API definitions are uploaded to 42Crunch Platform, not retrieved from URLs, Security Audit cannot infer the default scheme and thus the scheme must be defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-schemes-undefined.shortDescription: You have not defined the schemes field in your API.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
swagger: "2.0"
info:
  version: 1.0.0
  title: Swagger Petstore
host: petstore.swagger.io
basePath: /v1
schemes: []

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined at least one scheme for your API:

code.yaml:
swagger: "2.0"
info:
  version: 1.0.0
  title: Swagger Petstore
host: petstore.swagger.io
basePath: /v1
schemes:
  - https

title.text: Security requirement is not an OAuth2 requirement and must not define OAuth2 scopes

description.text:
Description

The security requirement in question defines OAuth2 scopes. However, it is not an OAuth2 security requirement, and thus must not define OAuth2 scopes.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

semantic-securityrequirement-nonoauth2sc.shortDescription: The security requirement in question defines OAuth2 scopes. However, it is not an OAuth2 security requirement, and thus must not define OAuth2 scopes.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
schemes:
  - https
# ...
securityDefinitions:
  regularSecurity:
    type: basic
# ...
security:
  - regularSecurity:
      - readOnly
# ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that only OAuth2 security requirements define OAuth2 scopes.

code.yaml:
schemes:
  - https
# ...
securityDefinitions:
  regularSecurity:
    type: basic
# ...
security:
  - regularSecurity: []
# ...

title.text: API accepts HTTP requests in the clear

description.text:
Description

The API accepts HTTP communications in the clear. HTTP traffic is not encrypted and can thus be easily intercepted.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-http-clear.shortDescription: The API accepts HTTP communications in the clear. HTTP traffic is not encrypted and can thus be easily intercepted.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. The host server of the API accepts unencrypted connections:

code.yaml:
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.com

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

If your API supports unencrypted HTTP connections, all requests and responses are transmitted in the open. Anyone listening to the network traffic while the calls are being made may intercept them.

Remediation

Use only secure connections for the servers:

code.yaml:
servers:
  - url: https://my.api.com

title.text: Global 'security' field is not defined

description.text:
Description

The global security field of the API has not been defined. This field specifies if your API requires the API consumer to authenticate to use the API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-security.shortDescription: The global security field of the API has not been defined. This field specifies if your API requires the API consumer to authenticate to use the API.

sections.text:
Example

The security field is tightly coupled with the securitySchemes objects. The security field could be missing because:

  • You forgot to define the securitySchemes field altogether, leaving the API completely unprotected.
  • You defined the securitySchemes field but not the security field. The definitions are not actually getting applied.
  • You defined the securitySchemes field and the operation-level security field for some of the API operations. However, you did not define the security field on the global level for the whole API.

Possible exploit scenario

If you do not set the global security field, the API does not require any authentication by default. Anyone can use the API operations that do not have a security field defined. All they need to know is the URL for the API operation and how to invoke it.

This sometimes happens to internal APIs. These are often created only to be used inside the company web pages and mobile applications. No one expects any outsiders to know that the API exists, so developers do not spend time implementing security.

But attackers can look at the code of the mobile or web application, or listen to the API traffic, and reverse engineer how the API works. Once the attackers have figured this out, they can start using the API because it does not require any authentication.

Relying on defining security only on each operation individually is an error-prone approach. It is very easy to forget to set security when you add a new method to the API. If there is no global default security defined, the operation is left wide open for an attacker to invoke without any authentication required.

Remediation

First, define the securityDefinitions or securitySchemes field on the global level, and list the authentication methods that you plan to use. For example:

code.yaml:
components:
  securitySchemes:
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            readOnly: read objects in your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

sections.text:
Then, use the security field on the global level to set the default authentication requirements for the whole API.

If you have more than one definition in securitySchemes and you want to apply all of them for each API call, use the following syntax (semantically AND):

code.yaml:
security:
  - petstore_auth: []
    api_key: []

sections.text: If you want to apply only one of the definitions to an API call, use the following syntax (semantically OR):

code.yaml:
security:
  - petstore_auth: []
  - api_key: []

sections.text: You can add an exception to the security specified on the global level on the operation level as needed. This overrides the authentication requirements of the whole API. Simply add a separate security field to the operation in question.

title.text: Reusable security scheme is not defined

description.text:
Description

A reusable security scheme in #/components/securitySchemes has not been defined. This specifies how API clients must authenticate to use your API's operations.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securitydefinitions-undefined.shortDescription: A reusable security scheme in #/components/securitySchemes has not been defined. This specifies how API clients must authenticate to use your API's operations.

sections.text:
Example

The securitySchemes field could be missing altogether, or the field could be empty, with no security schemes specified:

code.yaml:
components:
  securitySchemes: {}

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

Without any reusable security schemes, your API does not globally specify any authentication method for consuming the API operations. This means that anyone can use API operations as long as they know the URLs of the operations and how to invoke them.

This sometimes happens to internal APIs. These are often created only to be used inside the company web pages and mobile applications. No one expects any outsiders to know that the API exists, so developers do not spend time implementing security.

But attackers can look at the code of the mobile or web application, or listen to the API traffic, and reverse engineer how the API works. Once the attackers have figured this out, they can start using the API because it does not require any authentication.

Remediation

First, define the security schemes in #/components/securitySchemes:

code.yaml:
components:
  securitySchemes:
    api_key1:
      type: apiKey
      name: X-Api_Key
      in: header

sections.text: Then, use the global security field to set your API to require authentication:

code.yaml:
security:
  api_key1: []

title.text: Credentials transported over network

description.text:
Description

The API accepts credentials (basic authentication credentials or API keys) transported over the network. The credentials are sent over the network on each API call, over and over again, and are exposed to attack attempts to retrieve them.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityrequirement-average.shortDescription: The API accepts credentials (basic authentication credentials or API keys) transported over the network. The credentials are sent over the network  on each API call, over and over again, and are exposed to attack attempts to retrieve them.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. Here, the authentication method is specified to be regularSecurity that uses basic authentication:

code.yaml:
security:
  - regularSecurity: []
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic
    api_key:
      type: apiKey
      name: api_key
      in: header

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

Attackers can eavesdrop credentials transported over the network and try to intercept the traffic between the API consumer and your API to retrieve them. If they succeed, they can access all API operations protected with the same security requirement until the credentials are specifically revoked or changed. Both basic credentials and API keys have long lifetime providing extended opportunity for exploits.

Remediation

Use a more secure security definition, like OAuth 2.0. Instead of just credentials, OAuth 2.0 uses access tokens with limited lifetime and authorizations (the scopes) granted that the Resource Owner grants from an authorization server.

An API operation can be consumed only if the request includes an access token and the scopes of the token match the scopes that the API operation requires. Even if attackers successfully retrieved access tokens, they can only use the token on a subset of the API operation and for a limited time.

code.yaml:
security:
  - OAuth2:
      - readOnly
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            readOnly: read objects in your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

title.text: Credentials sent as cleartext

description.text:
Description

Your API accepts user credentials sent in cleartext over an unencrypted channel. Attackers can easily intercept API calls and retrieve the credentials. They can then use the credentials to make other API calls.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityrequirement-clearcrede.shortDescription: Your API accepts user credentials sent in cleartext over an unencrypted channel. Attackers can easily intercept API calls and retrieve the credentials. They can then use the credentials to make other API calls.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
security:
  - regularSecurity: []
# ...
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic

sections.text: The security field defines that the API is protected with basic authentication. The reusable security scheme regularSecurity defines that type of the transport protocol is HTTP, which is matched by the URL of the server for the API.

Possible exploit scenario

Attackers can intercept the credentials simply by listening to the network traffic in a public WiFi network. They could also use a traffic logging tool on a smartphone, computer, or browser, or sniff the traffic in the network to get the credentials.

Remediation

At the very least, set the transport protocol to HTTPS only so that all traffic is encrypted. You could also improve the security of the authentication method. The OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code flow (Access Code flow in OAS v2) is considered the most secure way to provide API authorization.

code.yaml:
security:
  - OAuth2:
      - readOnly
# ...
servers:
  - url: https://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            readOnly: read objects in your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

title.text: 'Security' field contains an empty array

description.text:
Description

The security field of your API contract does not list any security schemes to be applied. Instead, it just contains an empty array.

The top-level security field of the OpenAPI contract contains an array of the security schemes applied to the whole API. The list of values describes alternative security schemes that can be used. There is a logical OR between the security requirements. Individual operations can override the top-level security in the operation-level security fields if needed.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityrequirement-emptyarray.shortDescription: The security field of your API contract does not list any security schemes to be applied. Instead, it just contains an empty array.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. An empty array in the security field does not apply any security scheme, and thus does not protect the API:

code.yaml:
# ... 
info:
  title: Petstore API
paths:
  {}
  # ...
security: []

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

Even though you can apply security schemes directly to individual operations, it is strongly recommended that you define your default security schemes on the API level. The operation-level security is meant to be used as an exception-handling mechanism only, not as a best practice.

Relying on defining security only on each operation individually is an error-prone approach. It is very easy to forget to set security when you add a new method to the API. If there is no global default security defined, the operation is left wide open for an attacker to invoke without any authentication required.

Remediation

Make sure you define default security on the global level for the whole API, and only define exceptions to this on the operation level, if needed.

code.yaml:
security:
  - OAuth2:
      - readOnly
# ...
servers:
  - url: https://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            readOnly: read objects in your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

title.text: 'Security' field contains an empty security requirement

description.text:
Description

One or more of the objects defined in the global security field contain an empty security requirement. The security field specifies what kind of authentication your API requires. An empty requirement in the security field disables the authentication completely.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityrequirement-emptyschem.shortDescription: One or more of the objects defined in the global security field contain an empty security requirement. The security field specifies what kind of authentication your API requires. An empty requirement in the security field disables the authentication completely.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. The security field contains an empty object:

code.yaml:
security:
  - {}
# ...
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

An empty requirement in the security field disables the authentication completely. Attackers could access any API operations without any authentication and identification, and try to retrieve or push some incorrect data, like SQL injection or JSON hijacking. Without the first level of access control, you have no possibility to revoke their access in case you spot incorrect behavior.

Remediation

Make sure you specify at least one security requirement in your security scheme to apply authentication to API operations.

code.yaml:
security:
  - regularSecurity: []
# ...
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic

title.text: OAuth2 security requirement requires a scope not declared in the referenced security scheme

description.text:
Description

The OAuth2 security requirement in the security field requires a scope that has not been defined in the security scheme of your API. The security field specifies what kind of authentication your API requires.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityrequirement-oauth2-sco.shortDescription: The OAuth2 security requirement in the security field requires a scope that has not been defined in the security scheme of your API. The security field specifies what kind of authentication your API requires.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
security:
  OAuth2:
    - readWrite
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            read: read objects in your account
            write: write objects to your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

If you do not lock down all scopes the OAuth 2 security requirement can use, attackers could try to introduce their scopes to fill the gap.

Attackers could, for example, specify an arbitrary scope containing an SQL injection or buffer overflow attack that is triggered when your API requests a token from the token URL. By limiting the scopes that the OAuth flow can use only to those defined in the OAuth2 security scheme, you ensure that only the strings you have specified are allowed through to the token endpoint. An unrecognized scope in the token request could also lead the attackers gaining extended permissions to access the your resources.

Remediation

Ensure that all OAuth2 scopes referenced in the security requirements have a match in the OAuth2 security scheme, or remove the undefined scopes.

code.yaml:
security:
  OAuth2:
    - read
    - write
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            read: read objects in your account
            write: write objects to your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

title.text: Access tokens transported as cleartext

description.text:
Description

Access tokens are transported in the clear over an unencrypted channel. Attackers can easily intercept API calls and retrieve the tokens. They can then use the tokens to make other API calls.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
security:
  - OAuth2:
      - readOnly
# ...
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            readOnly: read objects in your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

Possible exploit scenario

Attackers can intercept the access tokens simply by listening to the network traffic in a public WiFi network. They could also use a traffic logging tool on a smartphone, computer, or browser, or sniff the traffic in the network to get the tokens.

Remediation

Set the URL in the server object to HTTPS only so that all traffic is encrypted.

# ...

title.text: Transporting credentials over the network allowed

description.text:
Description

One or more global security schemes allows transporting credentials (basic authentication credentials or API keys) over the network. The credentials are sent over the network on each API call, over and over again, and are exposed to attack attempts to retrieve them.

This is a potential risk, because the definition is in security schemes. However, it easily turns into an actual risk when the unsafe method is used in a security requirement.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityscheme-average.shortDescription: One or more global security schemes allows transporting credentials (basic authentication credentials or API keys) over the network. The credentials are sent over the network  on each API call, over and over again, and are exposed to attack attempts to retrieve them.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic
    api_key:
      type: apiKey
      name: api_key
      in: header

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

Attackers can eavesdrop credentials transported over the network and try to intercept the traffic between the API consumer and your API to retrieve them. If they succeed, they can access all API operations protected with the same security requirement until the credentials are specifically revoked or changed. Both basic credentials and API keys have long lifetime providing extended opportunity for exploits.

Remediation

Use a more secure security definition, like OAuth 2.0. Instead of just credentials, OAuth 2.0 uses access tokens with limited lifetime and authorizations (the scopes) granted that the Resource Owner grants from an authorization server.

An API operation can be consumed only if the request includes an access token and the scopes of the token match the scopes that the API operation requires. Even if attackers successfully retrieved access tokens, they can only use the token on a subset of the API operation and for a limited time.

code.yaml:
components:
  securitySchemes:
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            readOnly: read objects in your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

title.text: Sending credentials as cleartext allowed

description.text:
Description

One or more global security schemes in the API allows to set security requirements that accept user credentials sent in cleartext over an unencrypted channel. Attackers can easily intercept API calls and retrieve the credentials. They can then use the credentials to make other API calls.

This is a potential risk, because the definition is in security schemes. However, it easily turns into an actual risk when the unsafe method is used in a security requirement.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityscheme-clearcredential.shortDescription: One or more global security schemes in the API allows to set security requirements that accept user credentials sent in cleartext over an unencrypted channel. Remediation

At the very least, set the URL in the server object to HTTPS only so that all traffic is encrypted.

title.text: Authorization URL of the OAuth2 security scheme is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The API accepts basic credentials transported over the network. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityscheme-oauth2-authoriz.shortDescription: The API accepts basic credentials transported over the network. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

sections.text:
Possible exploit scenario

Depending on the underlying library used, your API consumer might be redirected to nefarious sites when parsing non-standard URLs.

In addition, TLS certificates use the URL's host name to validate that the presented certificate matches the host that was contacted. An invalid host name could potentially scupper this validation. A badly encoded URL could be used as an attack vector when decoding the resource path.

Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

title.text: Token URL of the OAuth2 security scheme is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL you have entered in the tokenUrl field of the OAuth2 security scheme is not a proper URL. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-global-securityscheme-oauth2-tokenurl.shortDescription: The URL you have entered in the tokenUrl field of the OAuth2 security scheme is not a proper URL. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.
