                  uuid:
                    type: string
                    format: uuid
          links:
            address:
              operationId: getAddress
              parameters:
                userId: $request.path.id
  "/users/{userid}/address":
    parameters:
      - name: userid
        in: path
        required: true
        description: the user identifier, as userId
        schema:
          type: string
          additionalProperties: false
    get:
      operationId: getUserAddress
      responses:
        "200":
          description: the user's address

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all operationId properties in link objects match the operationId properties of the operations you want to link to.

code.yaml:
paths:
  "/users/{id}":
    parameters:
      - name: id
        in: path
        required: true
        description: the user identifier, as userId
        schema:
          type: string
          additionalProperties: false
    get:
      responses:
        "200":
          description: the user being returned
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
                additionalProperties: false
                properties:
                  uuid:
                    type: string
                    format: uuid
          links:
            address:
              operationId: getUserAddress
              parameters:
                userId: $request.path.id
  "/users/{userid}/address":
    parameters:
      - name: userid
        in: path
        required: true
        description: the user identifier, as userId
        schema:
          type: string
          additionalProperties: false
    get:
      operationId: getUserAddress
      responses:
        "200":
          description: the user's address

title.text: Key used in the encoding map of the schema is not defined in the properties of the schema

description.text:
Description

The encoding map of a schema you have defined for a media type object contains a key that is not defined in the properties of the schema.

The encoding property of a media type object maps the schema's property name to a specific encoding. All keys in the encoding map must be defined as properties in the schema.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-mediatype-encoding-key-undef.shortDescription: The encoding map of a schema you have defined for a media type object contains a key that is not defined in the properties of the schema.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition The key historyMetadata in the encoding map has not been defined in the schema of the media type object:

code.yaml:
requestBody:
  content:
    multipart/mixed:
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        properties:
          id:
            type: string
            format: uuid
          address:
            type: object
            properties: {}
          type: object
          properties: {}
        profileImage:
          type: string
          format: binary
    encoding:
      historyMetadata:
        contentType: application/xml; charset=utf-8

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all keys in the encoding map are defined in the schema of the media type object.

code.yaml:
requestBody:
  content:
    multipart/mixed:
      schema:
        type: object
        additionalProperties: false
        properties:
          id:
            type: string
            format: uuid
          address:
            type: object
            properties: {}
          historyMetadata:
            description: metadata in XML format
            type: object
            properties: {}
          profileImage:
            type: string
            format: binary
      encoding:
        historyMetadata:
          contentType: application/xml; charset=utf-8

title.text: Uploading multiple files is only available for 'multipart/*' media type

description.text:
Description

The Content-Type you have defined for the media type object only allows uploading a single file. To upload multiple files, you must set Content-Type to multipart.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-mediatype-multiplefile.shortDescription: The Content-Type you have defined for the media type object only allows uploading a single file. To upload multiple files, you must set Content-Type to multipart.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The schema of the media type object defines an array of files, but the Content-Type does not allow uploading multiple files:

code.yaml:
requestBody:
  content:
    application/octet-stream:
      schema:
        properties:
          file:
            type: array
            additionalProperties: false
            items:
              type: string
              format: binary

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that if you want to enable uploading multiple files, you have set the Content-Type of the media type object to multipart.

code.yaml:
requestBody:
  content:
    " multipart/form-data":
      schema:
        additionalProperties: false
        properties:
          file:
            type: array
            items:
              type: string
              format: binary

title.text: 'OperationId' is not unique throughout the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

The operation does not have a unique operationID. All operations in your API must have unique operation IDs.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-operation-id.shortDescription: The operation does not have a unique operationID. All operations in your API must have unique operation IDs.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all operations in your API have a unique operationID.

title.text: Property 'allowEmptyValue' is only allowed for query parameters

description.text:
Description

The parameter in question has the allowEmptyValue property defined, but it is not a query or a formData parameter. Only query and formData parameters can have the allowEmptyValue property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-parameter-allowemptyvalue.shortDescription: The parameter in question has the allowEmptyValue property defined, but it is not a query or a formData parameter. Only query and formData parameters can have the allowEmptyValue property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The parameter has allowEmptyValue set to true, but in is set to path:

code.yaml:
myAPIparameter:
  name: id
  in: path
  required: true
  allowEmptyValue: true
  schema:
    $ref: "#/components/schemas/id"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that only query and formData parameters have the allowEmptyValue property.

code.yaml:
myAPIparameter:
  name: id
  in: query
  required: true
  allowEmptyValue: true
  schema:
    $ref: "#/components/schemas/id"

title.text: Property 'allowReserved' is only allowed for query parameters

description.text:
Description

You have defined the property allowReserved for a parameter where it is not allowed. The property is only allowed for query parameters.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-parameter-allowreserved.shortDescription: You have defined the property allowReserved for a parameter where it is not allowed. The property is only allowed for query parameters.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The parameter has allowReserved set to true, but in is set to path:

code.yaml:
myAPIparameter:
  name: string
  in: path
  required: true
  allowReserved: true
  schema:
    $ref: "#/components/schemas/string"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure you only define allowReserved for query parameters.

code.yaml:
myAPIparameter:
  name: string
  in: query
  required: true
  allowReserved: true
  schema:
    $ref: "#/components/schemas/string"

title.text: Parameters have the same name + in combination

description.text:
Description

Two or more parameters have the same nameIn combination (parameter name + in). The nameIn combinations must be unique.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-parameter-namein-multiple.shortDescription: Two or more parameters have the same nameIn combination (parameter name + in). The nameIn combinations must be unique.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all parameters have unique nameIn combinations.

title.text: Header parameters have the same name

description.text:
Description

Two or more header parameters have properties name that are considered equal.

While parameter names normally are case-sensitive, RFC 7230 states that HTTP header names are not. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) does therefore not consider header parameters names as case-sensitive, so names like content-type and Content-Type are considered equal. You should not have equal header parameters in your OpenAPI definition.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-parameter-namein-multiple-he.shortDescription: Two or more header parameters have properties name that are considered equal.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: Auth-Token
    in: header
    description: Auth-Token
    required: true
    type: string
  - name: auth-token
    in: header
    description: Authorization token for user
    required: true
    type: string

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all header parameters have unique name.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: Auth-Token
    in: header
    description: Auth-Token
    required: true
    type: string
  - name: auth-token
    in: header
    description: Authorization token for user
    required: true
    type: string

title.text: Path parameter in the path has no corresponding path template

description.text:
Description

The path parameter in question does not have a corresponding path template.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-parameter-nopathtemplate.shortDescription: The path parameter in question does not have a corresponding path template.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all path parameters have corresponding path templates, or remove the parameters that do not have them.

title.text: Path template for the path is empty

description.text:
Description

The path template for the path in question is empty and has not been defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-parameter-path-name-empty.shortDescription: The path template for the path in question is empty and has not been defined.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all paths have path templates defined.

title.text: Path template has no corresponding path parameter definition

description.text:
Description

The path in question includes one ore more path parameters that do not have corresponding parameters in the path template.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-parameter-path-undefined.shortDescription: The path in question includes one ore more path parameters that do not have corresponding parameters in the path template.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all path parameters have corresponding parameters in the path templates, or remove the parameters that do not correspond the path template.

title.text: Paths are equivalent

description.text:
Description

Your API contains paths that are equivalent. In practice, these paths are considered to be identical because there is no way of telling them apart.

This can happen, for example, if you have defined same path but with different parameter name for different operations. The parameter name alone does not make the path unique.

The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) states that all paths must be unique.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-path-equivalent.shortDescription: Your API contains paths that are equivalent. In practice, these paths are considered to be identical because there is no way of telling them apart.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. GET and PUT operations have the same path but different parameter:

code.yaml:
paths:
  "/path/{IDs}":
    get:
      description: Get the ID list
      parameters:
        name: IDs
        in: path
        required: true
        type: string
        # ...
  "/path/{addIDs}":
    put:
      description: Add IDs to the ID list
      parameters:
        name: addIDs
        in: path
        required: true
        type: string
        # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Define a single path /path/{parameter} with multiple operations (here GET and PUT):

code.yaml:
"/path/{IDs}":
  get:
    description: Get the ID list
    parameters:
      name: IDs
      in: path
      required: true
      type: string
      # ...
  put:
    description: Add IDs to the ID list
    parameters:
      name: addIDs
      in: path
      required: true
      type: string
      # ...

sections.text: If you need multiple paths, make sure that all paths are considered unique.

title.text: Schema property is not unique throughout 'properties', 'allOf', and 'additionalProperties' fields

description.text:
Description

Two or more schema properties have duplicate keys. Schema properties must have unique keys throughout all properties, allOf, and additionalProperties fields.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-property-duplicate-key.shortDescription: Two or more schema properties have duplicate keys. Schema properties must have unique keys throughout all properties, allOf, and additionalProperties fields.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all schema properties have unique keys.

title.text: Required property is missing

description.text:
Description

Your API is missing one or more properties that the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines as required. If you do not define all required properties, your API definition does not fully conform to the OAS.

The names of objects and properties are case-sensitive, so make sure that you have spelled them correctly.

The following objects themselves are optional, but if defined in the API definition, must have the following properties defined:

Object Required properties
External Documentation url
Discriminator propertyName
License name
Request Body content
Response description
Server Variable default
Tag name

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-property-required.shortDescription: Your API is missing one or more properties that the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines as required. If you do not define all required properties, your API definition does not fully conform to the OAS.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The license object of this sample API is missing the field name, which is defined as a required property in the OAS:

code.yaml:
license:
  description: This is a sample license.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that your API has all the properties that the OAS requires.

code.yaml:
license:
  name: My Sample License
  description: This is a sample license.

title.text: HTTP status codes in responses must be between 100 and 599

description.text:
Description

One or more responses objects in your API have non-standard HTTP response code keys. The HTTP response code keys must be between 100 and 599.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-response-httpstatus.shortDescription: One or more responses objects in your API have non-standard HTTP response code keys. The HTTP response code keys must be between 100 and 599.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the response code has a typo and is missing one number:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "20":
    description: Expected response to a valid request
    schema:
      $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pets"

sections.text: Or your response code might be bigger than the maximum defined in the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) Status Code Registry:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "659":
    description: Response to the error XYZ
    schema:
      $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pets"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all responses objects have HTTP response code keys between 100 and 599.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: Expected response to a valid request
    schema:
      $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pets"

title.text: Default value for the schema property is not consistent with the property's type

description.text:
Description

The default value you have defined for a schema property is not consistent with the type of the property.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-schema-default-invalid.shortDescription: The default value you have defined for a schema property is not consistent with the type of the property.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all default values for schema properties match the property type.

title.text: Enum value for the schema is not consistent with the schema's type

description.text:
Description

The enum value you have specified for a schema does not match the type of the schema.

v3-semantic-schema-enum-type-incompatibl.shortDescription: The enum value you have specified for a schema does not match the type of the schema.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all enum values for schemas match the type of schema.

title.text: Schema does not define a required property

description.text:
Description

One or more properties that you have defined as required are not defined in the schema.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-schema-property-required.shortDescription: One or more properties that you have defined as required are not defined in the schema.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The schema requires the property name, but it has not been defined:

code.yaml:
name: Pet
in: body
description: pet to add to the system
required: true
schema:
  type: object
  additionalProperties: "false"
  required:
    - name
  properties:
    breed:
      type: string
    age:
      type: integer

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties you have defined as required are also defined in the schema.

code.yaml:
name: pet
in: body
description: pet to add to the system
required: true
schema:
  type: object
  additionalProperties: "false"
  required:
    - name
  properties:
    name:
      type: string
    breed:
      type: string
    age:
      type: integer

title.text: Security requirement is not an OAuth2 or OpenID Connect requirement and must not define scopes

description.text:
Description

The security requirement in question defines authorization scopes. However, it is not an OAuth2 or OpenID Connect security requirement, and thus must not define scopes.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-securityrequirement-nonoauth.shortDescription: The security requirement in question defines authorization scopes. However, it is not an OAuth2 or OpenID Connect security requirement, and thus must not define scopes.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
api_key:
  - write:pets
  - read:pets

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that only OAuth2 and OpenID Connect security requirements define scopes.

code.yaml:
api_key: []
# ...
petstore_oauth:
  - write:pets
  - read:pets

title.text: Server object variable is not used in any server URLs

description.text:
Description

The variable you have defined in the server variables is not used in any URLs in your API definition. All variables defined in the variables property map of the server object must be used in an url property in the API definition.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-server-parameter-url-undefin.shortDescription: The variable you have defined in the server variables is not used in any URLs in your API definition. All variables defined in the variables property map of the server object must be used in an url property in the API definition.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The variable foo has been defined in the variables map, but is not used in the URL:

code.yaml:
servers:
  - url: https://{username}.gigantic-server.com:{port}/{basePath}
    description: The production API server
    variables:
      port:
        enum:
          - "8443"
          - "443"
        default: "8443"
      basePath:
        default: v2
      foo:
        default: bar

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all variables you have defined in the variables maps of server objects are either used in URLs or removed.

code.yaml:
servers:
  - url: https://{user-name}.gigantic-server.com:{port}/{basePath}
    description: The production API server
    variables:
      username:
        default: demo
        description: this value is assigned by the service provider, in this example
          `gigantic-server.com`
      port:
        enum:
          - "8443"
          - "443"
        default: "8443"
      basePath:
        default: v2

title.text: Server URL must be an absolute URL

description.text:
Description

The property url of the server object must be an absolute URL.

The Open API Specification (OAS) states that a server object may have a relative URL but that this indicates that the host location is relative to the location where the OpenAPI document is being served. Because API definitions are uploaded to 42Crunch Platform, not retrieved from URLs, Security Audit cannot infer the host location and thus relative URLs are not acceptable.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-server-url.shortDescription: The property url of the server object must be an absolute URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The server object has been defined, but as a relative URL:

code.yaml:
openapi: 3.0.0
servers:
  - url: /api
info:
  {}
  # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Define the URL of the server object as an absolute URL.

code.yaml:
openapi: 3.0.0
servers:
  - url: http://petstore.swagger.io/api
info:
  {}
  # ...

title.text: Server object variable used in the server URL is not defined in the server object variables

description.text:
Description

The variable you are using in the URL is not defined in the server variables in your API. All variables used in the url property must be defined as a key in the variables property map of the server object.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-server-variables-undefined.shortDescription: The variable you are using in the URL is not defined in the server variables in your API. All variables used in the url property must be defined as a key in the variables property map of the server object.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The variable username is used in the URL, but it has not been defined in the variables map:

code.yaml:
servers:
  - url: https://{username}.gigantic-server.com:{port}/{basePath}
    description: The production API server
    variables:
      port:
        enum:
          - "8443"
          - "443"
        default: "8443"
      basePath:
        default: v2

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined all variables used in URLs in the variables map of a server object.

code.yaml:
servers:
  - url: https://{user-name}.gigantic-server.com:{port}/{basePath}
    description: The production API server
    variables:
      username:
        default: demo
        description: this value is assigned by the service provider, in this example
          `gigantic-server.com`
      port:
        enum:
          - "8443"
          - "443"
        default: "8443"
      basePath:
        default: v2

title.text: At least one server must be defined

description.text:
Description

You have not defined any servers for your API. You must define at least one server for your API in the top-level servers field.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-semantic-servers-required.shortDescription: You have not defined any servers for your API. You must define at least one server for your API in the top-level servers field.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml: servers: {}

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined at least one server for your API.

code.yaml:
servers:
  url: https://my.api.server.com/
  description: My API server

sections.text: OAS v3 also supports defining an array of multiple servers for a single API:

code.yaml:
servers:
  - url: https://my.api.server1.com/
    description: API server 1
  - url: https://my.api.server2.com/
    description: API server 2

title.text: Array must not be empty

description.text:
Description

The definition of the array in question is empty. Array must not be void.

v3-validation-array-void.shortDescription: The definition of the array in question is empty. Array must not be void.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that arrays do not have empty definitions.

title.text: Multiple entries in the 'content' property of a parameter

description.text:
Description

You have defined more than one entry in the content property of the parameter object in question. The content property cannot contain more than one entry.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-content-length.shortDescription: You have defined more than one entry in the content property of the parameter object in question. The content property cannot contain more than one entry.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: foo
    in: header
    content:
      application/json:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/SchemaOne"
      text/xml:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/SchemaTwo"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined only one entry in the content property of a parameter object.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: foo
    in: header
    content:
      application/json:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/SchemaOne"

title.text: Property value is not an enum that the OpenAPI Specification allows for this property

description.text:
Description

One or more values you have defined for properties constrained by enums do not conform to the OpenAPI Specification (OAS).

v3-validation-enum-entry-badvalue.shortDescription: One or more values you have defined for properties constrained by enums do not conform to the OpenAPI Specification (OAS).

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all values you have defined for properties constrained by enums follow the OAS.

title.text: Paths in your API definition are not exposed

description.text:
Description

The paths in your API definition are empty and thus not exposed. This could happen, for example, if you did not have the proper access rights when retrieving the API specification file.

The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) allows the paths to be empty, but it probably is not what you want to do.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-global-paths-empty.shortDescription: The paths in your API definition are empty and thus not exposed. This could happen, for example, if you did not have the proper access rights when retrieving the API specification file.

sections.text:
Remediation

Check that you have defined the paths you want to expose in your API.

title.text: Security field references a security scheme not defined in '#/components/securitySchemes'

description.text:
Description

A security requirement in the security field contains a reference to a security scheme that is not defined in the API.

The security field specifies what kind of authentication your API requires, either on global level for the whole API or for individual API operations.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-global-securityrequirement.shortDescription: A security requirement in the security field contains a reference to a security scheme that is not defined in the API.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The security field references an OAuth security scheme, but this scheme has not been defined in #/components/securitySchemes:

code.yaml:
security:
  - regularSecurity: []
    OAuth2:
      - readOnly
# ...
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all security schemes that the security field references are defined.

code.yaml:
security:
  - regularSecurity: []
    OAuth2:
      - readOnly
# ...
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            readOnly: read objects in your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

title.text: Key does not match the allowed pattern

description.text:
Description

A key in a map you have defined does not match the regex defined for the components object. All keys must follow the regular expression ^[a-zA-Z0-9\.\-_]+$.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-key-pattern.shortDescription: A key in a map you have defined does not match the regex defined for the components object. All keys must follow the regular expression ^[a-zA-Z0-9\.\-_]+$.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
securitySchemes:
  api key:
    type: apiKey
    name: API key
    in: header

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all keys match the regex allowed for the components object.

code.yaml:
securitySchemes:
  api_key:
    type: apiKey
    name: API key
    in: header

title.text: Encoding object can only be defined for 'multipart/*' and 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' media types

description.text:
Description

You have defined an encoding object for an object which media type does not allow an encoding object. Encoding object is only applicable to request body objects with multipart/* and application/x-www-form-urlencoded media types.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-media-type-encoding-restri.shortDescription: You have defined an encoding object for an object which media type does not allow an encoding object. Encoding object is only applicable to request body objects with multipart/* and application/x-www-form-urlencoded media types.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure you only define encoding object for request body objects with multipart/* and application/x-www-form-urlencoded media types.

title.text: Security field of the operation references a security scheme not defined in '#/components/securitySchemes'

description.text:
Description

A security requirement in the security field contains a reference to a security scheme that is not defined in the API.

The security field specifies what kind of authentication your API requires, either on global level for the whole API or for individual API operations.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-operation-securityrequirem.shortDescription: A security requirement in the security field contains a reference to a security scheme that is not defined in the API.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The security field references an OAuth security scheme, but this scheme has not been defined in #/components/securitySchemes:

code.yaml:
security:
  - regularSecurity: []
    OAuth2:
      - readOnly
# ...
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all security schemes that the security field references are defined.

code.yaml:
security:
  - regularSecurity: []
    OAuth2:
      - readOnly
# ...
servers:
  - url: http://my.api.server.com/
    description: API server
# ...  
components:
  securitySchemes:
    regularSecurity:
      type: http
      scheme: basic
    OAuth2:
      type: oauth2
      flows:
        authorizationCode:
          scopes:
            readOnly: read objects in your account
          authorizationUrl: https://example.com/oauth/authorize
          tokenUrl: https://example.com/oauth/token

title.text: Path parameter must have the property 'required' set to 'true'

description.text:
Description

The required property of the path parameter in question is either missing altogether, or it is set to false. All path parameters must have the property required set to true.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-parameter-path-required.shortDescription: The required property of the path parameter in question is either missing altogether, or it is set to false. All path parameters must have the property required set to true.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the property required is set to false:

code.yaml:
name: ID
in: path
description: ID to fetch
required: false
type: integer
# ...

sections.text: While here, the property has been forgotten altogether:

code.yaml:
name: ID
in: path
description: ID to fetch
type: integer
# ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all path parameters have the required property set to true.

code.yaml:
name: ID
in: path
description: ID to fetch
required: true
type: integer
# ...

title.text: Parameter object defines neither a schema nor a content property

description.text:
Description

You have defined neither the schema nor content property for one or more parameter objects in your API. All parameters must have either schema or content property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-parameter-schema-content-n.shortDescription: You have defined neither the schema nor content property for one or more parameter objects in your API. All parameters must have either schema or content property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
"/pets/{id}":
  get:
    description: Returns a user based on a single ID, if the user does not have
      access to the pet
    operationId: find pet by id
    parameters:
      - name: id
        in: path
        description: ID of pet to fetch
        required: true

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined either the schema or content property for all parameter objects in your API.

code.yaml:
"/pets/{id}":
  get:
    description: Returns a user based on a single ID, if the user does not have
      access to the pet
    operationId: find pet by id
    parameters:
      - name: id
        in: path
        description: ID of pet to fetch
        required: true
        schema:
          type: integer
          additionalProperties: false
          format: int64

title.text: Parameter defines both a schema property and a content property

description.text:
Description

You have defined both the schema and content properties for one or more parameter objects in your API. Each parameter must have either schema or content property defined, but not both.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-parameter-schema-content-p.shortDescription: You have defined both the schema and content properties for one or more parameter objects in your API. Each parameter must have either schema or content property defined, but not both.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
"/pets/{id}":
  get:
    description: Returns a user based on a single ID, if the user does not have
      access to the pet
    operationId: find pet by id
    parameters:
      - name: id
        in: path
        description: ID of pet to fetch
        required: true
        schema:
          type: integer
          format: int64
        content:
          application/json:
            schema:
              $ref: "#/components/schemas/user"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined either the schema or content property for all parameter objects in your API.

code.yaml:
"/pets/{id}":
  get:
    description: Returns a user based on a single ID, if the user does not have
      access to the pet
    operationId: find pet by id
    parameters:
      - name: id
        in: path
        description: ID of pet to fetch
        required: true
        schema:
          type: integer
          additionalProperties: false
          format: int64

title.text: Required dependent property of an existing property is missing

description.text:
Description

The property in question is defined in such a way that another property that depends on it is required. However, the required property is missing.

v3-validation-property-dependency-unsati.shortDescription: The property in question is defined in such a way that another property that depends on it is required. However, the required property is missing.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all required operations are defined in your API, or define properties in a way that does not require dependent properties to be present.

title.text: Property defining a maximum is not greater than the corresponding property defining the minimum

description.text:
Description

Properties defining maximums (maximum, maxLegth, or maxItems) must have values that are greater than the values of the corresponding minimum properties (minimum, minLegth, or minItems). However, the value you have defined for the maximum is not greater than the value you have defined for the minimum.

v3-validation-property-greater.shortDescription: Properties defining maximums (maximum, maxLegth, or maxItems) must have values that are greater than the values of the corresponding minimum properties (minimum, minLegth, or minItems). However, the value you have defined for the maximum is not greater than the value you have defined for the minimum.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined maximum values that are greater than the corresponding minimum values.

title.text: Property must have an integer value

description.text:
Description

The property in question requires a value of the type integer, but the value you have defined does not match this.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

v3-validation-property-integer.shortDescription: The property in question requires a value of the type integer, but the value you have defined does not match this.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined values that match the type that the properties require.

title.text: Property must have a positive integer value

description.text:
Description

The property in question requires a positive value of the type integer, but the value you have defined does not match this.

v3-validation-property-integer-positive.shortDescription: The property in question requires a positive value of the type integer, but the value you have defined does not match this.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined values that match the type that the properties require.

title.text: Value of the numeric property is too big for the defined type

description.text:
Description

The value you have defined for a numeric property is too big for the type of that property.

v3-validation-property-overflow.shortDescription: The value you have defined for a numeric property is too big for the type of that property.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined values for numeric properties that are not too big for the types of the properties.

title.text: Mandatory property is missing

description.text:
Description

Your API is missing one or more properties that are mandatory. Either the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines them as required, or defining them is mandatory for 42Crunch Platform to be able to properly use your API definition.

The names of objects and properties are case-sensitive, so make sure that you have spelled them correctly.

The following objects and properties are the bare minimum that the OAS requires from an OpenAPI definition and must always be defined:

  • openapi
  • info
    • title
    • version
  • paths

The following objects themselves are optional, but if defined in the API definition, must have the following properties defined:

Object Required properties
Operation responses
Parameter
  • name
  • in
Security Scheme type

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-property-required.shortDescription: Your API is missing one or more properties that are mandatory. Either the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines them as required, or defining them is mandatory for 42Crunch Platform to be able to properly use your API definition.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The info object of this sample API is missing the field version, which is defined as a required property in the OAS:

code.yaml:
info:
  title: My Sample API
  description: This is a sample API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that your API has all the properties that the OAS requires.

code.yaml:
info:
  version: 1.0.0
  title: My Sample API
  description: This is a sample API.

title.text: Property value has different type than what the OpenAPI Specification requires for this property

description.text:
Description

The property in question has a value of a type does not match the required type.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

v3-validation-property-value-type.shortDescription: The property in question has a value of a type does not match the required type.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the values of all properties match the types required.

title.text: Callback cannot be a JSON reference pointing outside '#/components/callback'

description.text:
Description

One or more JSON references to reusable callbacks in your API point outside the #/components/callback object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable callbacks must point to a callback object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-callback.shortDescription: One or more JSON references to reusable callbacks in your API point outside the #/components/callback object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable callbacks must point to a callback object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, a reusable callback has been defined, but it is incorrectly referenced from parameters and therefore ignored:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "201":
    description: subscription created
    content:
      {}
      # ...
    callbacks:
      callback_1:
        $ref: "#/components/parameters/reusableCallback"
# ...
components:
  # ...
  callbacks:
    onData:
      "{$request.query.callbackUrl}/data":
        post:
          requestBody:
            description: subscription payload
            content:
              application/json:
                schema:
                  properties:
                    timestamp:
                      type: string
                      format: date-time
                    userData:
                      type: string

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all JSON references to reusable links point to #/components/callbacks.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "201":
    description: subscription created
    content:
      {}
      # ...
    callbacks:
      callback_1:
        $ref: "#/components/callbacks/reusableCallback"

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the callback does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the callback cannot be found in your API. You must define the target callback in your API.

v3-validation-reference-callback-unresol.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the callback cannot be found in your API. You must define the target callback in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Circular reference is not allowed

description.text:
Description

One or more schemas in your API have a circular reference, meaning that they reference themselves at the same level.

For example, a schema object in allOf must not reference the schema holding the allOf property. Same applies to oneOf, anyOf and not properties.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-circular.shortDescription: One or more schemas in your API have a circular reference, meaning that they reference themselves at the same level.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have not defined any circular references for the schemas in your API.

title.text: Example cannot be a JSON reference pointing outside '#/components/examples'

description.text:
Description

One or more JSON references to reusable examples in your API point outside the #/components/examples object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable examples must point to an example object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-example.shortDescription: One or more JSON references to reusable examples in your API point outside the #/components/examples object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable examples must point to an example object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, a reusable example has been defined, but it is incorrectly references from schemas and therefore ignored:

code.yaml:
content:
  application/json:
    schema:
      type: array
      items:
        $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"
    examples:
      objectExample:
        $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all JSON references to reusable examples point to #/components/examples.

code.yaml:
content:
  application/json:
    schema:
      type: array
      items:
        $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"
    examples:
      objectExample:
        $ref: "#/components/examples/Pet"

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the example does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the example cannot be found in your API. You must define the target example in your API.

v3-validation-reference-example-unresolv.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the example cannot be found in your API. You must define the target example in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Header cannot be a JSON reference pointing outside '#/components/headers'

description.text:
Description

One or more JSON references to reusable headers in your API point outside the #/components/headers object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable headers must point to a header object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-header.shortDescription: One or more JSON references to reusable headers in your API point outside the #/components/headers object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable headers must point to a header object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all JSON references to reusable headers point to #/components/headers.

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the header does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the header cannot be found in your API. You must define the target header in your API.

v3-validation-reference-header-unresolve.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the header cannot be found in your API. You must define the target header in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Link cannot be a JSON reference pointing outside '#/components/links'

description.text:
Description

One or more JSON references to reusable links in your API point outside the #/components/links object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable links mus point to a link object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-link.shortDescription: One or more JSON references to reusable links in your API point outside the #/components/links object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable links mus point to a link object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, a reusable link has been defined, but it is incorrectly referenced from schemas and therefore ignored:

code.yaml:
get:
  operationId: getUserByName
  parameters:
    - name: username
      in: path
      required: true
      schema:
        type: string
  responses:
    "200":
      description: The User
      content:
        application/json:
          schema:
            $ref: "#/components/schemas/user"
      links:
        userRepositories:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/UserRepositories"
# ...
components:
  links:
    UserRepositories:
      operationId: getRepositoriesByOwner
      parameters:
        username: $response.body#/username

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all JSON references to reusable links point to #/components/links.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: The User
    content:
      application/json:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/user"
    links:
      userRepositories:
        $ref: "#/components/links/UserRepositories"

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the link does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the link cannot be found in your API. You must define the target link in your API.

v3-validation-reference-link-unresolved.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the link cannot be found in your API. You must define the target link in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Parameter cannot be a JSON reference that points outside of the '#/components/parameters'

description.text:
Description

You have defined the reusable parameter in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the #/components/parameters object. This is not possible.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-parameter.shortDescription: You have defined the reusable parameter in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the #/components/parameters object. This is not possible.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all reusable parameters are defined in the #/components/parameters object.

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the parameter does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the parameter cannot be found in your API. You must define the target parameter in your API.

v3-validation-reference-parameter-unreso.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the parameter cannot be found in your API. You must define the target parameter in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: External references at the path item level are not supported

description.text:
Description

You have defined the path item in question as an external reference. External references are not supported at the path item level.

v3-validation-reference-pathitem.shortDescription: You have defined the path item in question as an external reference. External references are not supported at the path item level.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not define path items as external references.

title.text: Request body cannot be a JSON reference pointing outside '#/components/requestBodies'

description.text:
Description

One or more JSON references to reusable request bodies in your API point outside the #/components/requestBodies object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable request bodies must point to a requestBody object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-requestbody.shortDescription: One or more JSON references to reusable request bodies in your API point outside the #/components/requestBodies object in the API definition. The $ref of all reusable request bodies must point to a requestBody object in the components object, otherwise they have no effect.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, a reusable request body has been defined, but it is incorrectly referenced from schemas and therefore ignored:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Add a new pet
  requestBody:
    $ref: "#/components/schemas/petRequestBody"
# ...
components:
  requestBodies:
    petRequestBody:
      description: A JSON object for reusable request body containing the details of a pet
      required: true
      content:
        application/json:
          schema:
            $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all JSON references to reusable request bodies point to #/components/requestBodies.

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Add a new pet
  requestBody:
    $ref: "#/components/requestBodies/petRequestBody"

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the request body does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the request body cannot be found in your API. You must define the target request body in your API.

v3-validation-reference-requestbody-unre.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the request body cannot be found in your API. You must define the target request body in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Response cannot be a JSON reference that points outside of the '#/components/responses'

description.text:
Description

You have defined the reusable response in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the #/components/responses object. This is not possible.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-response.shortDescription: You have defined the reusable response in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the #/components/responses object. This is not possible.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all reusable responses are defined in the #/components/responses object.

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the response does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the response cannot be found in your API. You must define the target response in your API.

v3-validation-reference-response-unresol.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the response cannot be found in your API. You must define the target response in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Schema cannot be a JSON reference that points outside of the '#/components/schemas'

description.text:
Description

You have defined the reusable schema in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the #/components/schemas object. This is not possible.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-reference-schema.shortDescription: You have defined the reusable schema in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the #/components/schemas object. This is not possible.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all reusable schemas are defined in the #/components/schemas object.

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the schema does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the schema cannot be found in your API. You must define the target schema in your API.

v3-validation-reference-schema-unresolve.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the schema cannot be found in your API. You must define the target schema in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Responses object must contain at least one HTTP response code or a default response

description.text:
Description

One or more responses objects in your API are empty. The responses objects must contain at least one HTTP response code key, preferably for a successful operation. Alternatively, you can set the responses object to use the default response you have defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-response-empty.shortDescription: One or more responses objects in your API are empty. The responses objects must contain at least one HTTP response code key, preferably for a successful operation. Alternatively, you can set the responses object to use the default response you have defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  # ...
  responses: {}

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all responses objects have a HTTP response code key defined or the value default.

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  # ...
  responses:
    "200":
      description: Expected response to a valid request
      schema:
        $ref: "#/components/responses/Pet"

title.text: Schema is an array, the 'items' property must be defined

description.text:
Description

The schema in question is an array schema, but you have not defined the items property for it. Array schemas must have the items property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-schema-array-items.shortDescription: The schema in question is an array schema, but you have not defined the items property for it. Array schemas must have the items property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: user
in: body
description: The user to be added
required: true
schema:
  type: array

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all array schemas have the items property defined.

code.yaml:
name: user
in: body
description: The user to be added
required: true
schema:
  type: array
  additionalProperties: false
  items:
    type: string

title.text: Schema is not an array, the 'items' property must not be defined

description.text:
Description

The schema in question is not an array schema, but you have defined the items property for it. Non-array schemas must not have the items property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-schema-notarray-items.shortDescription: The schema in question is not an array schema, but you have defined the items property for it. Non-array schemas must not have the items property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
description: A simple response returning the name of the pet
schema:
  type: string
  items:
    {}
    # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that non-array schemas do not have the items property defined.

code.yaml:
description: A simple response returning the name of the pet
schema:
  type: string

title.text: Schema object property has both 'writeOnly' and 'readOnly' set to 'true'

description.text:
Description

One or more properties in the schema you have defined has both writeOnly and readOnly properties set to true. You can define a property to be either "write only" or "read only", but not both.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-schema-write-read-only.shortDescription: One or more properties in the schema you have defined has both writeOnly and readOnly properties set to true. You can define a property to be either "write only" or "read only", but not both.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
type: object
properties:
  id:
    type: integer
    readOnly: true
    writeOnly: true
  name:
    type: string

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined either the schema or content property for all parameter objects in your API.

code.yaml:
type: object
properties:
  id:
    type: integer
    readOnly: true
  name:
    type: string

title.text: OAuth2 security scheme defines a property not applicable to the defined OAuth2 flow

description.text:
Description

You have defined a property for your security scheme that is not applicable to the OAuth2 flow you have chosen.

v3-validation-security-oauth-exclusive.shortDescription: You have defined a property for your security scheme that is not applicable to the OAuth2 flow you have chosen.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have define only properties applicable to your chosen OAuth2 flow in your OAuth2 security schemes.

title.text: OAuth2 security scheme does not define a property that the defined OAuth2 flow requires

description.text:
Description

Some security schemes for OAuth2 flows in your API require the property in question. You must define the property.

v3-validation-security-oauth-required.shortDescription: Some security schemes for OAuth2 flows in your API require the property in question. You must define the property.

sections.text:
Remediation

Replace with the description of how to fix the issue.

title.text: Security scheme does not define a required property

description.text:
Description

Some security schemes in your API require the property in question. You must define the property.

v3-validation-security-required.shortDescription: Some security schemes in your API require the property in question. You must define the property.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties required by security schemes are defined correctly.

title.text: Security scheme defines a property not applicable to it

description.text:
Description

You have defined a property that is exclusive for some security schemes. However, other security schemes can use this property too. You must exclude the property from the latter security schemes.

v3-validation-security-type-exclusive.shortDescription: You have defined a property that is exclusive for some security schemes. However, other security schemes can use this property too. You must exclude the property from the latter security schemes.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that exclusive properties are not used by security schemes that the properties are not defined for.

title.text: Property is not defined in the OpenAPI Specification

description.text:
Description

The property you have defined is unknown. This property is not included in the OpenAPI Specification (OAS).

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-validation-unknown-property.shortDescription: The property you have defined is unknown. This property is not included in the OpenAPI Specification (OAS).

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The OAS does not recognize a property called language for strings:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  in: query
  name: id
  type: string
  maxLength: 8
  language: en-US
  description: Identifier of the object to be extracted.

sections.text:
Remediation

Do not use unknown properties not defined in the OAS.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  in: query
  name: id
  type: string
  maxLength: 8
  description: Identifier of the object to be extracted.

title.text: Contact object email is not a proper email address

description.text:
Description

The email address defined the email field of the contact object is not a proper email address. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that email addresses in the contract must be proper email addresses in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-contact-email.shortDescription: The email address defined the email field of the contact object is not a proper email address. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that email addresses in the contract must be proper email addresses in a valid format.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
contact:
  name: API Team
  email: will add later

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all email addresses are proper email addresses and have the valid format.

code.yaml:
contact:
  name: API Team
  email: contact@apisecurity.io

title.text: Contact object URL is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined the url field of the contact object is not a proper URL. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-contact-url.shortDescription: The URL defined the url field of the contact object is not a proper URL. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. In this example, the URL is missing the protocol and has an extra space in the middle:

code.yaml:
name: API Support
url: www.example.com/ support
email: support@example.com

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
name: API Support
url: www.example.com/support
email: support@example.com

title.text: MIME type has an improper value

description.text:
Description

The value you have defined for the MIME type is not a proper value. For example, it might contain characters that are not allowed, or it might not follow the format prefix/subtype[+suffix][;parameters].

For more details, see RFC 6838.

v3-warning-content-type-badformat.shortDescription: The value you have defined for the MIME type is not a proper value. For example, it might contain characters that are not allowed, or it might not follow the format prefix/subtype[+suffix][;parameters].

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The prefix, subtype, and suffix are separated by spaces:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: Cute cat picture
    content:
      image svg xml:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/Kitty"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all MIME type definitions follow the format prefix/subtype[+suffix][;parameters] and do not contain restricted characters.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: Cute cat picture
    content:
      image/svg+xml:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/Kitty"

title.text: Prefix is not a known prefix

description.text:
Description

You are referencing a media type using an unknown prefix. All media types referenced should be proper MIME types.

Known prefixes for media types are:

  • application
  • audio
  • font
  • example
  • image
  • message
  • model
  • multipart
  • text
  • video

For more details, see RFC 2046.

v3-warning-content-type-unknownprefix.shortDescription: You are referencing a media type using an unknown prefix. All media types referenced should be proper MIME types.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The media type prefix has been misspelt:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: Expected response to a valid request
    content:
      aplication/json:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you only use known media type prefixes.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: Expected response to a valid request
    content:
      application/json:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"

title.text: Property 'allowReserved' of the encoding object is ignored because of the media type of the request body

description.text:
Description

The allowReserved property you have defined for the encoding object is ignored because the media type of the request body is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-encoding-allowreserved.shortDescription: The allowReserved property you have defined for the encoding object is ignored because the media type of the request body is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the media type of the request body is application/x-www-form-urlencoded to apply the allowReserved property to encoding.

title.text: Property 'explode' of the encoding object is ignored because of the media type of the request body

description.text:
Description

The property explode of the encoding object is ignored because of the media type of the request body is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-encoding-explode.shortDescription: The property explode of the encoding object is ignored because of the media type of the request body is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the media type of the request body is application/x-www-form-urlencoded to apply the explode property to encoding.

title.text: Header 'Content-Type' of an encoding object is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have included Content-Type in the headers field of your encoding object. However, for encoding objects, Content-Type is defined separately and is ignored inside the headers field.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-encoding-header-content-type.shortDescription: You have included Content-Type in the headers field of your encoding object. However, for encoding objects, Content-Type is defined separately and is ignored inside the headers field.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
encoding:
  historyMetadata:
    contentType: application/xml; charset=utf-8
  profileImage:
    headers:
      Content-Type:
        contentType: image/png, image/jpeg
      X-Rate-Limit-Limit:
        description: The number of allowed requests in the current period
        schema:
          type: integer

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you define Content-Type separately, and not in the headers field.

code.yaml:
encoding:
  historyMetadata:
    contentType: application/xml; charset=utf-8
  profileImage:
    contentType: image/png, image/jpeg
    headers:
      X-Rate-Limit-Limit:
        description: The number of allowed requests in the current period
        schema:
          type: integer
          additionalProperties: false

title.text: Property 'style' of the encoding object is ignored because of the media type of the request body

description.text:
Description

The property style of the encoding object is ignored because of the media type of the request body is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-encoding-style.shortDescription: The property style of the encoding object is ignored because of the media type of the request body is not application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the media type of the request body is application/x-www-form-urlencoded to apply the style property to encoding.

title.text: Example is not consistent with the underlying schema

description.text:
Description

The example object you have defined is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-example-schema-not-consistent.shortDescription: The example object you have defined is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the example objects you define match the schemas of their associated values.

title.text: Reusable callback definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable callback you have defined in #/components/callbacks is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-callback-unused.shortDescription: A reusable callback you have defined in #/components/callbacks is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable callbacks, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: Reusable example definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable example you have defined in #/components/examples is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-example-unused.shortDescription: A reusable example you have defined in #/components/examples is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable examples, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: External Documentation object URL is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined the url field of the top-level External Documentation object is not a proper URL.

You can use the externalDocs field to reference an external resource that offers extended documentation for your API. This is field is optional. However, if you do reference external documentation, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-externaldocumentation-.shortDescription: The URL defined the url field of the top-level External Documentation object is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the url field has just a placeholder string:

code.yaml:
externalDocs:
  description: Additional documentation
  url: need to add later

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
externalDocs:
  description: Additional documentation
  url: http://my.api.com/docs

title.text: Reusable header definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable header you have defined in #/components/headers is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-header-unused.shortDescription: A reusable header you have defined in #/components/headers is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable headers, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: Reusable link definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable link you have defined in #/components/links is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-link-unused.shortDescription: A reusable link you have defined in #/components/links is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:

title.text: Reusable parameter definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable parameter you have defined in #/components/parameters is not used anywhere in your API.

v3-warning-global-parameter-unused.shortDescription: A reusable parameter you have defined in #/components/parameters is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:

title.text: Reusable request body definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable request body you have defined in #/components/requestBodies is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-request-body-unused.shortDescription: A reusable request body you have defined in #/components/requestBodies is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:

Remove unused reusable request bodies, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: Reusable response definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable response you have defined in #/components/responses is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-response-unused.shortDescription: A reusable response you have defined in #/components/responses is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:

title.text: Reusable schema definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable schema you have defined in #/components/schemas is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-schema-unused.shortDescription: A reusable schema you have defined in #/components/schemas is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable schemas, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: Reusable security scheme definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable security scheme you have defined in #/components/securitySchemes is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-global-security-scheme-unused.shortDescription: A reusable security scheme you have defined in #/components/securitySchemes is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable security schemes, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: License object URL is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined in the url field of the license object is not a proper URL.

The license object itself and the url field in it are optional. If you do not defined either, your OpenAPI definition is still a valid contract. However, if you do reference your license location, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification

v3-warning-license-url.shortDescription: The URL defined in the url field of the license object is not a proper URL.
