sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. In this case, the URL is missing the protocol prefix and has an extra space:

code.yaml:
license:
  name: Apache 2.0
  url: www.apache.org/licenses/ LICENSE-2.0.html

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
license:
  name: Apache 2.0
  url: www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.html

title.text: Encoding is not applicable to the media type of the request body

description.text:
Description

The encoding you have defined is not applicable to the defined media type of the request body. The encoding only applies to requestBody object when the media type is either multipart or application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-media-type-encoding.shortDescription: The encoding you have defined is not applicable to the defined media type of the request body. The encoding only applies to requestBody object when the media type is either multipart or application/x-www-form-urlencoded.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the media type of the request body is multipart or application/x-www-form-urlencoded to apply the encoding.

title.text: Media type object has no schema defined

description.text:
Description

One or more media type objects in your API do not have schemas defined. All media types should have schema defined to restrict what input your API accepts.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-media-type-schema.shortDescription: One or more media type objects in your API do not have schemas defined. All media types should have schema defined to restrict what input your API accepts.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. This request body would accept anything as input:

Remediation

Make sure that you have defined schemas for all media type objects in your API.

code.yaml:
requestBody:
  content:
    application/octet-stream:
      schema:
        type: string
        format: binary
        additionalProperties: false

title.text: 'External Documentation' URL of the operation is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined in the url field of the External Documentation object for the API operation in question is not a proper URL.

You can use the externalDocs field to reference an external resource that offers extended documentation for your API. This is field is optional. However, if you do reference external documentation, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-operation-externaldocumentati.shortDescription: The URL defined in the url field of the External Documentation object for the API operation in question is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. In this case, the URL is missing the protocol prefix and has a space in the middle:

code.yaml:
get:
  description: Returns all pets from the system that the user has access to
  produces:
    - application/json
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: will add later
  # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
get:
  description: Returns all pets from the system that the user has access to
  produces:
    - application/json
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: http://petstore.api.com/docs/pets
  # ...

title.text: Property 'allowEmptyValue' is ignored because of the defined 'style' behavior

description.text:
Description

The property allowEmptyValue you have defined for a parameter is ignored because of the style behavior you have defined for it.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-parameter-allow-empty-value-i.shortDescription: The property allowEmptyValue you have defined for a parameter is ignored because of the style behavior you have defined for it.

sections.text: If you want to apply allowEmptyValue to the parameter, make sure the style behavior allows it.

title.text: Header parameter with the name 'Accept' is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-parameter-header-accept.shortDescription: You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: Accept
in: header
description: Supported content types
required: true
schema:
  type: string
  pattern: ^application/json$|^application/xml$

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not use the restricted values as header parameter names.

title.text: Header parameter with the name 'Authorization' is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-parameter-header-authorizatio.shortDescription: You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: Authorization
in: header
description: token to be passed as a header
required: true
schema:
  type: array
  items:
    type: string
    format: base64
    additionalProperties: false
style: simple

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not use the restricted values as header parameter names.

Make sure that you have properly defined the security section of your OpenAPI definition and are not trying to use a header parameter to define what in fact should be conveyed in the actual Authorization header.

title.text: Header parameter with the name 'Content-Type' is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-parameter-header-content-type.shortDescription: You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: Content-Type
in: header
description: Supported content types
required: true
schema:
  type: string
  pattern: ^application/json$|^application/xml$

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not use the restricted values as header parameter names.

title.text: Default value unnecessarily declared for a required parameter type

description.text:
Description

You have specified a default value for a required parameter. The values for required parameters are always specified in requests, so there is no need to specify a default value that the server could use.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-parameter-required-default.shortDescription: You have specified a default value for a required parameter. The values for required parameters are always specified in requests, so there is no need to specify a default value that the server could use.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: pet to add to the system
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
            default: Fido
          # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not specify default responses for required parameters.

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: pet to add to the system
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
          # ...

title.text: Path has no operation defined

description.text:
Description

A path in your API has no operation defined in it. This could happen, for example, if you did not have the proper access rights when retrieving the API definition.

The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) allows paths that do not have operation, but it probably is not what you want to do.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-path-pathitems-empty.shortDescription: A path in your API has no operation defined in it. This could happen, for example, if you did not have the proper access rights when retrieving the API definition.

sections.text:
Remediation

Define operations for all paths your API exposes.

title.text: No properties allowed alongside a JSON reference

description.text:
Description

You have defined a property alongside a $ref JSON reference. This is not allowed.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-reference-property.shortDescription: You have defined a property alongside a $ref JSON reference. This is not allowed.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not define any properties alongside $ref properties.

title.text: Header with the name 'Content-Type' is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have used a restricted value as the name of a header. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-response-header-content-type.shortDescription: You have used a restricted value as the name of a header. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
headers:
  Content-type:
    application/json:
      schema:
        $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not use the restricted values as header parameter names.

code.yaml:
headers:
  Pet:
    application/json:
      schema:
        $ref: "#/components/schemas/Pet"

title.text: If operation has only one HTTP response defined, the HTTP status code should be for a success

description.text:
Description

One or more operations in your API have only one response defined for them, but the HTTP status code in the response definition is not for a successful operation.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-responses-http-status-success.shortDescription: One or more operations in your API have only one response defined for them, but the HTTP status code in the response definition is not for a successful operation.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all operations have at least one HTTP response for a successful operation defined.

title.text: Schema keyword used alongside enum

description.text:
Description

You have used a schema keyword alongside an enum. This is not allowed.

v3-warning-schema-enum-property-improper.shortDescription: You have used a schema keyword alongside an enum. This is not allowed.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that schema properties that should not appear alongside enums do not do so.

title.text: Value of the schema example is not consistent with the schema

description.text:
Description

The example object you have defined is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

v3-warning-schema-example-improper.shortDescription: The example object you have defined is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the example objects you define match the schemas of their associated values.

title.text: 'External Documentation' URL of the schema is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined the url field of the External Documentation object for the schema in question is not a proper URL.

You can use the externalDocs field to reference an external resource that offers extended documentation for your API. This is field is optional. However, if you do reference external documentation, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-schema-externaldocumentation-.shortDescription: The URL defined the url field of the External Documentation object for the schema in question is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the url field has just a placeholder string:

code.yaml:
schema:
  type: string
  format: email
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: need to add later

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
schema:
  type: string
  format: email
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: http://my.api.com/docs/email

title.text: Schema format is not applicable to the schema's type

description.text:
Description

The format you have specified for a schema is not consistent with the type you have defined for the schema. While this is acceptable, it may not be what you want.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

v3-warning-schema-format-improper.shortDescription: The format you have specified for a schema is not consistent with the type you have defined for the schema. While this is acceptable, it may not be what you want.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The type of the schema is integer, but the format is float which is not an integer format:

code.yaml:
User:
  type: object
  additionalProperties: false
  properties:
    id:
      type: integer
      format: float

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the formats of all schemas match the type of the schemas.

Numeric parameters type integer can have the format int32 or int64. Numeric parameters type number can have the format float or double.

code.yaml:
User:
  type: object
  additionalProperties: false
  properties:
    id:
      type: integer
      format: int32

title.text: Schema keyword is not applicable to the defined data type

description.text:
Description

The schema keyword you have defined is not applicable to the data type you have defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-schema-property-improper.shortDescription: The schema keyword you have defined is not applicable to the data type you have defined.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties defined for schema properties match the data type.

title.text: Value of the 'x-42c-sample' extension is not consistent with the schema

description.text:
Description

The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

v3-warning-schema-sample-improper.shortDescription: The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the x-42c-sample extension matches the schema of the associated value.

title.text: 'External Documentation' URL of the tag is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined the url field of the External Documentation object for a tag is not a proper URL.

You can use the externalDocs field to reference an external resource that offers extended documentation for your API. This is field is optional. However, if you do reference external documentation, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

v3-warning-tag-externaldocumentation-url.shortDescription: The URL defined the url field of the External Documentation object for a tag is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the url field has just a placeholder string:

code.yaml:
tag:
  name: pet
  description: Pet operations
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: need to add later

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
tag:
  name: pet
  description: Pet operations
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: http://petstore.api.com/docs/petsoperations

title.text: Property value is not an enum that the OpenAPI Specification allows for this property

description.text:
Description

One or more values you have defined for properties constrained by enums do not conform to the OpenAPI Specification (OAS).

validation-enum-entry-badvalue.shortDescription: One or more values you have defined for properties constrained by enums do not conform to the OpenAPI Specification (OAS).

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all values you have defined for properties constrained by enums follow the OAS.

title.text: Paths in your API definition are not exposed

description.text:
Description

The paths in your API definition are empty and thus not exposed. This could happen, for example, if you did not have the proper access rights when retrieving the API specification file.

The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) allows the paths to be empty, but it probably is not what you want to do.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-global-paths-empty.shortDescription: The paths in your API definition are empty and thus not exposed. This could happen, for example, if you did not have the proper access rights when retrieving the API specification file.

sections.text:
Remediation

Check that you have defined the paths you want to expose in your API.

title.text: Header is an array, the 'items' property must be defined

description.text:
Description

The header in question is an array, but you have not defined the items property for it. Array headers must have the items property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-header-array-items.shortDescription: The header in question is an array, but you have not defined the items property for it. Array headers must have the items property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
headers:
  x-ids:
    schema:
      type: array

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all array headers have the items property defined.

code.yaml:
headers:
  x-ids:
    schema:
      type: array
      items:
        {}
        # ...

title.text: Header is not an array, the 'items' property must not be defined

description.text:
Description

The header in question is not an array, but you have defined the items property for it. Non-array headers must not have the items property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-header-notarray-items.shortDescription: The header in question is not an array, but you have defined the items property for it. Non-array headers must not have the items property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
headers:
  x-ids:
    schema:
      type: integer
      items:
        {}
        # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that non-array headers do not have the items property defined.

code.yaml:
headers:
  x-ids:
    schema:
      type: integer

title.text: Parameter is an array, the 'items' property must be defined

description.text:
Description

The parameter in question is an array, but you have not defined the items property for it. Array parameters must have the items property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-parameter-array-items.shortDescription: The parameter in question is an array, but you have not defined the items property for it. Array parameters must have the items property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: ids
    in: query
    description: IDs to filter by
    required: true
    type: array

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all array parameters have the items property defined.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  - name: ids
    in: query
    description: IDs to filter by
    required: true
    type: array
    items:
      type: integer
      format: int32
      # ...

title.text: Body parameter defines a property not applicable to body parameters

description.text:
Description

The body parameter in question defines more properties than allowed. Body parameters must only define name, in , description, required and schema properties.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-parameter-body-additionalprop.shortDescription: The body parameter in question defines more properties than allowed. Body parameters must only define name, in , description, required and schema properties.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that body parameters only define name, in , description, required and schema properties. Remove other properties.

title.text: Body parameter must have the 'schema' property defined

description.text:
Description

The body parameter in question is missing the schema property. Body parameters must have the schema property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-parameter-body-required.shortDescription: The body parameter in question is missing the schema property. Body parameters must have the schema property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: pet to add to the system
      required: true

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all body parameters have the schema property defined.

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: pet to add to the system
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
          # ...

title.text: Value 'multi' for the property 'collectionFormat' is only allowed for query parameters

description.text:
Description

The parameter in question has the value multi defined for the property collectionFormat. However, the parameter is not a query or formData parameter. Only query and formData arrays can have collectionFormat set to multi.

The value multi value denotes multiple parameter instances instead of multiple values for a single instance, like other array format values.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-parameter-collectionformat.shortDescription: The parameter in question has the value multi defined for the property collectionFormat. However, the parameter is not a query or formData parameter. Only query and formData arrays can have collectionFormat set to multi.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The collectionFormat property has been defined for a body parameter:

code.yaml:
name: ID
in: body
description: ID of the account to be fetched
required: false
type: array
items:
  type: string
collectionFormat: multi

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that only query and formData array parameters have collectionFormat set to multi.

code.yaml:
name: id
in: query
description: ID of the account to be fetched
required: false
type: array
items:
  type: string
collectionFormat: multi

title.text: File parameter has no 'in: formData' property defined

description.text:
Description

The file parameter in question is does not have an in: formData property defined. All file parameters must have the in: formData property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-parameter-file.shortDescription: The file parameter in question is does not have an in: formData property defined. All file parameters must have the in: formData property defined.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all file parameters have the in: formData property defined.

title.text: Parameter is not an array, the 'items' property must not be defined

description.text:
Description

The parameter in question is not an array, but you have defined the items property for it. Non-array parameters must have the items property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-parameter-notarray-items.shortDescription: The parameter in question is not an array, but you have defined the items property for it. Non-array parameters must have the items property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  type: integer
  format: int32
  name: total
  in: query
  description: Number of the objects in the array.
  items:
    {}
    # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that non-array parameters do not have the items property defined.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  type: integer
  format: int32
  name: total
  in: query
  description: Number of the objects in the array.
  # ...

title.text: Non-body parameter must not define the 'schema' property

description.text:
Description

The parameter in question is not a body parameter, but it has the schema property defined. Non-body parameters must not have the schema property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-parameter-notbody-schema.shortDescription: The parameter in question is not a body parameter, but it has the schema property defined. Non-body parameters must not have the schema property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: IDs
in: query
description: IDs to fetch
required: false
schema:
  type: object
  required:
    - IDlist
  properties:
    IDlist:
      type: array
      items:
        type: integer
        # ...
      collectionFormat: multi

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that non-body parameters do not have the schema property defined.

code.yaml:
name: IDs
in: query
description: IDs to fetch
required: false
type: array
items:
  type: integer
  # ...
collectionFormat: multi

title.text: Path parameter must have the property 'required' set to 'true'

description.text:
Description

The required property of the path parameter in question is either missing altogether, or it is set to false. All path parameters must have the property required set to true.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-parameter-path-required.shortDescription: The required property of the path parameter in question is either missing altogether, or it is set to false. All path parameters must have the property required set to true.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the property required is set to false:

code.yaml:
name: ID
in: path
description: ID to fetch
required: false
type: integer
# ...

sections.text: While here, the property has been forgotten altogether:

code.yaml:
name: ID
in: path
description: ID to fetch
type: integer
# ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all path parameters have the required property set to true.

code.yaml:
name: ID
in: path
description: ID to fetch
required: true
type: integer
# ...

title.text: Required dependent property of an existing property is missing

description.text:
Description

The property in question is defined in such a way that another property that depends on it is required. However, the required property is missing.

validation-property-dependency-unsatisfi.shortDescription: The property in question is defined in such a way that another property that depends on it is required. However, the required property is missing.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all required operations are defined in your API, or define properties in a way that does not require dependent properties to be present.

title.text: Property defining a maximum is not greater than the corresponding property defining the minimum

description.text:
Description

Properties defining maximums (maximum, maxLegth, or maxItems) must have values that are greater than the values of the corresponding minimum properties (minimum, minLegth, or minItems). However, the value you have defined for the maximum is not greater than the value you have defined for the minimum.

validation-property-greater.shortDescription: Properties defining maximums (maximum, maxLegth, or maxItems) must have values that are greater than the values of the corresponding minimum properties (minimum, minLegth, or minItems). However, the value you have defined for the maximum is not greater than the value you have defined for the minimum.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined maximum values that are greater than the corresponding minimum values.

title.text: Property must have an integer value

description.text:
Description

The property in question requires a value of the type integer, but the value you have defined does not match this.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

validation-property-integer.shortDescription: The property in question requires a value of the type integer, but the value you have defined does not match this.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined values that match the type that the properties require.

title.text: Property must have a positive integer value

description.text:
Description

The property in question requires a positive value of the type integer, but the value you have defined does not match this.

validation-property-integer-positive.shortDescription: The property in question requires a positive value of the type integer, but the value you have defined does not match this.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined values that match the type that the properties require.

title.text: Value of the numeric property is too big for the type of the property

description.text:
Description

The value you have defined for a numeric property is too big for the type of that property.

validation-property-overflow.shortDescription: The value you have defined for a numeric property is too big for the type of that property.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have defined values for numeric properties that are not too big for the types of the properties.

title.text: Host or basePath property does not match the pattern constraining the host or basePath values

description.text:
Description

The property in question does not match the required pattern.

validation-property-pattern.shortDescription: The property in question does not match the required pattern.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties match the required patterns.

title.text: Mandatory property is missing

description.text:
Description

Your API is missing one or more properties that are mandatory. Either the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines them as required, or defining them is mandatory for 42Crunch Platform to be able to properly use your API definition.

The names of objects and properties are case-sensitive, so make sure that you have spelled them correctly.

The following objects and properties are the bare minimum that the OAS requires from an OpenAPI definition and must always be defined:

  • swagger
  • info
    • title
    • version
  • paths

The following objects themselves are optional, but if defined in the API definition, must have the following properties defined:

Object Required properties
Header type
Items type
Operation responses
Parameter (if not referenced)
  • name
  • type
  • in
Security Scheme type

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-property-required.shortDescription: Your API is missing one or more properties that are mandatory. Either the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines them as required, or defining them is mandatory for 42Crunch Platform to be able to properly use your API definition.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The info object of this sample API is missing the field version, which is defined as a required property in the OAS:

code.yaml:
info:
  title: My Sample API
  description: This is a sample API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that your API has all the properties that the OAS requires.

code.yaml:
info:
  version: 1.0.0
  title: My Sample API
  description: This is a sample API.

title.text: Property must be unique throughout the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

The property in question is not unique. All properties must be unique throughout your whole API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-property-unique.shortDescription: The property in question is not unique. All properties must be unique throughout your whole API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties in your API are unique.

title.text: Property value has different type than what the OpenAPI Specification requires for this property

description.text:
Description

The property in question has a value of a type does not match the required type.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

validation-property-value-type.shortDescription: The property in question has a value of a type does not match the required type.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the values of all properties match the types required.

title.text: Circular reference is not allowed

description.text:
Description

One or more schemas in your API have a circular reference, meaning that they reference themselves at the same level.

For example, a schema object in allOf must not reference the schema holding the allOf property. Same applies to oneOf, anyOf and not properties.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-reference-circular.shortDescription: One or more schemas in your API have a circular reference, meaning that they reference themselves at the same level.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have not defined any circular references for the schemas in your API.

title.text: Parameter cannot be a JSON reference that points outside '#/parameters'

description.text:
Description

You have defined the parameter in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the parameters object. This is not possible.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-reference-parameter.shortDescription: You have defined the parameter in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the parameters object. This is not possible.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all parameters that are JSON references are defined in the parameters object.

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the parameter does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the parameter cannot be found in your API. You must define the target parameter in your API.

validation-reference-parameter-unresolve.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the parameter cannot be found in your API. You must define the target parameter in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: External references at the path item level are not supported

description.text:
Description

You have defined the path item in question as an external reference. External references are not supported at the path item level.

validation-reference-pathitem.shortDescription: You have defined the path item in question as an external reference. External references are not supported at the path item level.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not define path items as external references.

title.text: Response cannot be a JSON reference that points outside '#/responses'

description.text:
Description

You have defined the response in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the responses object. This is not possible.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-reference-response.shortDescription: You have defined the response in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the responses object. This is not possible.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all responses that all JSON references are defined in the responses object.

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the response does not exist in the API

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the response cannot be found in your API. You must define the target response in your API.

validation-reference-response-unresolved.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the response cannot be found in your API. You must define the target response in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Schema cannot be a JSON reference that points outside '#/definitions'

description.text:
Description

You have defined the schema in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the definitions object. This is not possible.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-reference-schema.shortDescription: You have defined the schema in question as a JSON reference that points outside of the definitions object. This is not possible.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all schemas that are JSON references are defined in the definitions object.

title.text: Target of the JSON reference of the schema does not exist

description.text:
Description

The target of the JSON reference of the schema cannot be found in your API. You must define the target schema in your API.

validation-reference-schema-unresolved.shortDescription: The target of the JSON reference of the schema cannot be found in your API. You must define the target schema in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all targets of JSON references are defined in your API.

title.text: Responses object must contain at least one HTTP response code or a default response

description.text:
Description

One or more responses objects in your API are empty. The responses objects must contain at least one HTTP response code key, preferably for a successful operation. Alternatively, you can set the responses object to use the default response you have defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-response-empty.shortDescription: One or more responses objects in your API are empty. The responses objects must contain at least one HTTP response code key, preferably for a successful operation. Alternatively, you can set the responses object to use the default response you have defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  # ...
  responses: {}

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all responses objects have a HTTP response code key defined or the value default.

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  # ...
  responses:
    "200":
      description: Expected response to a valid request
      schema:
        $ref: "#/definitions/Pets"
    # ...

title.text: Schema is an array, the 'items' property must be defined

description.text:
Description

The schema in question is an array schema, but you have not defined the items property for it. Array schemas must have the items property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-schema-array-items.shortDescription: The schema in question is an array schema, but you have not defined the items property for it. Array schemas must have the items property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: user
in: body
description: The user to be added
required: true
schema:
  type: array

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all array schemas have the items property defined.

code.yaml:
name: user
in: body
description: The user to be added
required: true
schema:
  type: array
  additionalProperties: false
  items:
    type: string

title.text: Schema is not an array, the 'items' property must not be defined

description.text:
Description

The schema in question is not an array schema, but you have defined the items property for it. Non-array schemas must not have the items property defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-schema-notarray-items.shortDescription: The schema in question is not an array schema, but you have defined the items property for it. Non-array schemas must not have the items property defined.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
description: A simple response returning the name of the pet
schema:
  type: string
  items:
    {}
    # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that non-array schemas do not have the items property defined.

code.yaml:
description: A simple response returning the name of the pet
schema:
  type: string

title.text: OAuth2 security scheme defines a property not applicable to the defined OAuth2 flow

description.text:
Description

You have defined a property for your security scheme that is not applicable to the OAuth2 flow you have chosen.

validation-security-oauth-exclusive.shortDescription: You have defined a property for your security scheme that is not applicable to the OAuth2 flow you have chosen.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you have define only properties applicable to your chosen OAuth2 flow in your OAuth2 security schemes.

title.text: OAuth2 security scheme does not define a property that the defined OAuth2 flow requires

description.text:
Description

Some security schemes for OAuth2 flows in your API require the property in question. You must define the property.

validation-security-oauth-required.shortDescription: Some security schemes for OAuth2 flows in your API require the property in question. You must define the property.

sections.text:
Remediation

Replace with the description of how to fix the issue.

title.text: Security scheme does not define a required property

description.text:
Description

Some security schemes in your API require the property in question. You must define the property.

validation-security-required.shortDescription: Some security schemes in your API require the property in question. You must define the property.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties required by security schemes are defined correctly.

title.text: Security scheme defines a property not applicable to it

description.text:
Description

You have defined a property that is exclusive for some security schemes. However, other security schemes can use this property too. You must exclude the property from the latter security schemes.

validation-security-type-exclusive.shortDescription: You have defined a property that is exclusive for some security schemes. However, other security schemes can use this property too. You must exclude the property from the latter security schemes.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that exclusive properties are not used by security schemes that the properties are not defined for.

title.text: Property is not defined in the OpenAPI Specification

description.text:
Description

The property you have defined is unknown. This property is not included in the OpenAPI Specification (OAS).

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

validation-unknown-property.shortDescription: The property you have defined is unknown. This property is not included in the OpenAPI Specification (OAS).

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The OAS does not recognize a property called language for strings:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  in: query
  name: id
  type: string
  maxLength: 8
  language: en-US
  description: Identifier of the object to be extracted.

sections.text:
Remediation

Do not use unknown properties not defined in the OAS.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  in: query
  name: id
  type: string
  maxLength: 8
  description: Identifier of the object to be extracted.

title.text: Contact object email is not a proper email address

description.text:
Description

The email address defined the email field of the contact object is not a proper email address. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that email addresses in the contract must be proper email addresses in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-contact-email.shortDescription: The email address defined the email field of the contact object is not a proper email address. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that email addresses in the contract must be proper email addresses in a valid format.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
contact:
  name: API Team
  email: will add later

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all email addresses are proper email addresses and have the valid format.

code.yaml:
contact:
  name: API Team
  email: contact@apisecurity.io

title.text: Contact object URL is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined the url field of the contact object is not a proper URL. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-contact-url.shortDescription: The URL defined the url field of the contact object is not a proper URL. The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. In this example, the URL is missing the protocol and has an extra space in the middle:

code.yaml:
name: API Support
url: www.example.com/ support
email: support@example.com

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
name: API Support
url: www.example.com/support
email: support@example.com

title.text: MIME type has an improper value

description.text:
Description

The value you have defined for the MIME type is not a proper value. For example, it might contain characters that are not allowed, or it might not follow the format prefix/subtype[+suffix][;parameters].

For more details, see RFC 6838.

warning-content-type-badformat.shortDescription: The value you have defined for the MIME type is not a proper value. For example, it might contain characters that are not allowed, or it might not follow the format prefix/subtype[+suffix][;parameters].

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The prefix, subtype, and suffix are separated by spaces:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: Cute cat picture
    content:
      image svg xml:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/definitions/Kitty"
  # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all MIME type definitions follow the format prefix/subtype[+suffix][;parameters] and do not contain restricted characters.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: Cute cat picture
    content:
      image/svg+xml:
        schema:
          $ref: "#/definitions/Kitty"
  # ...

title.text: Prefix is not a known prefix

description.text:
Description

You are referencing a media type using an unknown prefix. All media types referenced should be proper MIME types.

Known prefixes for media types are:

  • application
  • audio
  • font
  • example
  • image
  • message
  • model
  • multipart
  • text
  • video

For more details, see RFC 2046.

warning-content-type-unknownprefix.shortDescription: You are referencing a media type using an unknown prefix. All media types referenced should be proper MIME types.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The media type prefix has been misspelt:

code.yaml:
/pets:
  put:
    summary: Updates a pet in the store with form data
    operationId: updatePetWithForm
    produces:
      - aplication/json
    parameters:
      []
      # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you only use known media type prefixes.

code.yaml:
/pets:
  put:
    summary: Updates a pet in the store with form data
    operationId: updatePetWithForm
    produces:
      - application/json
    parameters:
      []
      # ...

title.text: External Documentation object URL is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined the url field of the top-level External Documentation object is not a proper URL.

You can use the externalDocs field to reference an external resource that offers extended documentation for your API. This is field is optional. However, if you do reference external documentation, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-global-externaldocumentation-url.shortDescription: The URL defined the url field of the top-level External Documentation object is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the url field has just a placeholder string:

code.yaml:
externalDocs:
  description: Additional documentation
  url: need to add later

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
externalDocs:
  description: Additional documentation
  url: http://my.api.com/docs

title.text: Reusable parameter definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable parameter you have defined in #/parameters is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification

warning-global-parameter-unused.shortDescription: A reusable parameter you have defined in #/parameters is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable parameters, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: Reusable response definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable response you have defined in #/responses is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-global-response-unused.shortDescription: A reusable response you have defined in #/responses is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable responses, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: Reusable schema definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable schema you have defined in #/definitions is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification

warning-global-schema-unused.shortDescription: A reusable schema you have defined in #/definitions is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable schemas, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: Reusable security scheme definition is not used in the OpenAPI definition

description.text:
Description

A reusable security scheme you have defined in #/securityDefinitions is not used anywhere in your API.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-global-security-scheme-unused.shortDescription: A reusable security scheme you have defined in #/securityDefinitions is not used anywhere in your API.

sections.text:
Remediation

Remove unused reusable security schemes, or make sure they are used in the API.

title.text: Property constraining header values is defined even though the header's values are defined in an enum

description.text:
Description

You have specified a property constraining header values even though the header's values are defined in an enum. This makes little sense.

warning-header-enum-property-improper.shortDescription: You have specified a property constraining header values even though the header's values are defined in an enum. This makes little sense.

sections.text:
Remediation

Do not define unnecessary properties for headers constrained by enums.

title.text: Header format is not applicable to the header's type

description.text:
Description

The format you have specified for a header is not consistent with the type you have defined. While this is acceptable, it may not be what you want.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

warning-header-format-improper.shortDescription: The format you have specified for a header is not consistent with the type you have defined. While this is acceptable, it may not be what you want.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The header type is integer, but format is float which is not an integer format:

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: OK
    headers:
      x-ids:
        schema:
          type: integer
          format: float

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the formats of all headers match the type of the headers.

Numeric parameters type integer can have the format int32 or int64. Numeric parameters type number can have the format float or double.

code.yaml:
responses:
  "200":
    description: OK
    headers:
      x-ids:
        schema:
          type: integer
          format: int32

title.text: Header property is not applicable to the header's type

description.text:
Description

A property defined for a header is not applicable to the type of the header.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-header-property-improper.shortDescription: A property defined for a header is not applicable to the type of the header.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The rate limiting header can include parameters of the type integer, but the parameters also have the property maxLength defined which is a property of string parameters, not integers:

code.yaml:
headers:
  X-Rate-Limit-Limit:
    description: The number of requests allowed in the current period
    type: integer
    maxLength: 8
  # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties defined for headers match the header type.

code.yaml:
headers:
  X-Rate-Limit-Limit:
    description: The number of requests allowed in the current period
    type: integer
    maximum: 8
  # ...

title.text: Value of the 'x-42c-sample' extension is not consistent with the header

description.text:
Description

The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the associated header.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-header-sample-improper.shortDescription: The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the associated header.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the x-42c-sample extension matches the associated header.

title.text: Property constraining the item values is defined even though the item's values are defined in an enum

description.text:
Description

You have specified a property constraining the values of array items even though the items' values are defined in an enum. This makes little sense.

warning-items-enum-property-improper.shortDescription: You have specified a property constraining the values of array items even though the items' values are defined in an enum. This makes little sense.

sections.text:
Remediation

Do not define unnecessary properties for array items constrained by enums.

title.text: Item format is not applicable to the type the array items

description.text:
Description

The format you have specified for one or more array items is not consistent with their type. While this is acceptable, it probably is not what you want.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

warning-items-format-improper.shortDescription: The format you have specified for one or more array items is not consistent with their type. While this is acceptable, it probably is not what you want.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The array accepts items of the type integer, but the format float is not an integer format:

code.yaml:
name: lockCombo
in: body
description: Lock combination to add to the list
required: true
schema:
  type: object
  required:
    - combination
  properties:
    combination:
      type: array
      items:
        type: integer
        format: float

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the formats of all array items match the type of the items.

Numeric parameters type integer can have the format int32 or int64. Numeric parameters type number can have the format float or double.

code.yaml:
name: lockCombo
in: body
description: Lock combination to add to the list
required: true
schema:
  type: object
  required:
    - combination
  properties:
    combination:
      type: array
      items:
        type: integer
        format: int32

title.text: Property defined for an array item is not applicable to the array item type

description.text:
Description

A property defined for an array item is not applicable to the type of the array item.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-items-property-improper.shortDescription: A property defined for an array item is not applicable to the type of the array item.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The array accepts string items but also has the property maximum defined which is a property of integers and numbers:

code.yaml:
name: someArray
in: body
type: array
items:
  type: string
  pattern: ^((4\d{3})|(5[1-5]\d{2})|(6011))-?\d{4}-?\d{4}-?\d{4}|3[4,7]\d{13}$
  maximum: 8

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties defined for array items match the array item type.

code.yaml:
name: someArray
in: body
type: array
items:
  type: string
  pattern: ^((4\d{3})|(5[1-5]\d{2})|(6011))-?\d{4}-?\d{4}-?\d{4}|3[4,7]\d{13}$
  maxLength: 8

title.text: Value of the 'x-42c-sample' extension is not consistent with the items

description.text:
Description

The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the associated array items.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-items-sample-improper.shortDescription: The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the associated array items.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the x-42c-sample extension matches the associated array items.

title.text: License object URL is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined in the url field of the license object is not a proper URL.

The license object itself and the url field in it are optional. If you do not defined either, your OpenAPI definition is still a valid contract. However, if you do reference your license location, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification

warning-license-url.shortDescription: The URL defined in the url field of the license object is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. In this case, the URL is missing the protocol prefix and has an extra space:

code.yaml:
license:
  name: Apache 2.0
  url: www.apache.org/licenses/ LICENSE-2.0.html

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
license:
  name: Apache 2.0
  url: www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.html

title.text: 'External Documentation' URL of the operation is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined in the url field of the External Documentation object for the API operation in question is not a proper URL.

You can use the externalDocs field to reference an external resource that offers extended documentation for your API. This is field is optional. However, if you do reference external documentation, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-operation-externaldocumentation-.shortDescription: The URL defined in the url field of the External Documentation object for the API operation in question is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. In this case, the URL is missing the protocol prefix and has a space in the middle:

code.yaml:
get:
  description: Returns all pets from the system that the user has access to
  produces:
    - application/json
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: will add later
  # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
get:
  description: Returns all pets from the system that the user has access to
  produces:
    - application/json
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: http://petstore.api.com/docs/pets
  # ...

title.text: Operation summary should be less than 120 characters

description.text:
Description

To be easier to read, an operation summary should be less than 120 characters long.

warning-operation-summary.shortDescription: To be easier to read, an operation summary should be less than 120 characters long.

sections.text:
Remediation

Condense all operation summaries to be under 120 characters.

title.text: Property constraining parameter values is defined even though the parameter's values are defined in an enum

description.text:
Description

You have specified a parameter property constraining parameter values even though the parameter's values are defined in an enum. This makes little sense.

warning-parameter-enum-property-improper.shortDescription: You have specified a parameter property constraining parameter values even though the parameter's values are defined in an enum. This makes little sense.

sections.text:
Remediation

Do not define unnecessary parameter properties for parameters constrained by enums.

title.text: Parameter format is not applicable to the parameter's type

description.text:
Description

The format you have specified for a parameter is not consistent with the type you have defined for the parameter. While this is acceptable, it may not be what you want.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

warning-parameter-format-improper.shortDescription: The format you have specified for a parameter is not consistent with the type you have defined for the parameter. While this is acceptable, it may not be what you want.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The type of the parameter is integer, but the format is float which is not an integer format:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  type: integer
  name: total
  in: query
  format: float
  description: Number of the objects in the array.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the formats of all parameters match the type of the parameters.

Numeric parameters type integer can have the format int32 or int64. Numeric parameters type number can have the format float or double.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  type: integer
  name: total
  in: query
  format: int32
  description: Number of the objects in the array.

title.text: Header parameter with the name 'Accept' is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

warning-parameter-header-accept.shortDescription: You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: Accept
in: header
description: Supported content types
required: true
type: string
pattern: ^application/json$|^application/xml$

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not use the restricted values as header parameter names.

title.text: Header parameter with the name 'Authorization' is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

warning-parameter-header-authorization.shortDescription: You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: Authorization
in: header
description: token to be passed as a header
required: true
type: array
items:
  type: integer
  format: int64
collectionFormat: csv

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not use the restricted values as header parameter names.

Make sure that you have properly defined the security section of your OpenAPI definition and are not trying to use a header parameter to define what in fact should be conveyed in the actual Authorization header.

title.text: Header parameter with the name 'Content-Type' is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

warning-parameter-header-content-type.shortDescription: You have used a restricted value as the name of a header parameter. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
name: Content-Type
in: header
description: Supported content types
required: true
type: string
pattern: ^application/json$|^application/xml$

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not use the restricted values as header parameter names.

title.text: Parameter property is not applicable to the parameter's type

description.text:
Description

A property defined for a parameter is not applicable to the type of the parameter.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-parameter-property-improper.shortDescription: A property defined for a parameter is not applicable to the type of the parameter.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The string parameter has the property maximum defined which is a property of integers and numbers:

code.yaml:
parameters:
  in: query
  name: id
  type: string
  description: Identifier of the object to be extracted.
  maximum: 8

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all properties defined for parameters match the parameter type.

code.yaml:
parameters:
  in: query
  name: id
  type: string
  description: Identifier of the object to be extracted.
  maxLength: 8

title.text: Default value unnecessarily declared for a required parameter type

description.text:
Description

You have specified a default value for a required parameter. The values for required parameters are always specified in requests, so there is no need to specify a default value that the server could use.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-parameter-required-default.shortDescription: You have specified a default value for a required parameter. The values for required parameters are always specified in requests, so there is no need to specify a default value that the server could use.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition:

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: pet to add to the system
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
            default: Fido
          # ...

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not specify default responses for required parameters.

code.yaml:
post:
  description: Creates a new pet in the store
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: pet to add to the system
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        required:
          - name
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
          # ...

title.text: Value of the 'x-42c-sample' extension is not consistent with the parameter

description.text:
Description

The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the associated parameter.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-parameter-sample-improper.shortDescription: The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the associated parameter.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the x-42c-sample extension matches the associated parameter.

title.text: Path has no operation defined

description.text:
Description

A path in your API has no operation defined in it. This could happen, for example, if you did not have the proper access rights when retrieving the API definition.

The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) allows paths that do not have operation, but it probably is not what you want to do.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-path-pathitems-empty.shortDescription: A path in your API has no operation defined in it. This could happen, for example, if you did not have the proper access rights when retrieving the API definition.

sections.text:
Remediation

Define operations for all paths your API exposes.

title.text: No properties allowed alongside a JSON reference

description.text:
Description

You have defined a property alongside a $ref JSON reference. This is not allowed.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-reference-property.shortDescription: You have defined a property alongside a $ref JSON reference. This is not allowed.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not define any properties alongside $ref properties.

title.text: Header with the name 'Content-Type' is ignored

description.text:
Description

You have used a restricted value as the name of a header. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

warning-response-header-content-type.shortDescription: You have used a restricted value as the name of a header. The values Accept, Content-Type, and Authorization are restricted values and should not be used as the header name. A header with any of these values as the header name is ignored.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that you do not use the restricted values as header names.

title.text: If operation has only one HTTP response defined, the HTTP status code should be for a success

description.text:
Description

One or more operations in your API have only one response defined for them, but the HTTP status code in the response definition is not for a successful operation.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-responses-http-status-successful.shortDescription: One or more operations in your API have only one response defined for them, but the HTTP status code in the response definition is not for a successful operation.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all operations have at least one HTTP response for a successful operation defined.

title.text: Schema defines 'additionalProperties' as a boolean value

description.text:
Description

The schema defines additionalProperties as a Boolean value.

The reason additionalProperties takes a boolean value comes from the role the attribute plays in JSON schemas. In JSON, by default, any object can also accept additional properties that are not defined in its schema as long as the properties defined in the schema are present. To change this behavior and stop allowing any additional properties to those explicitly defined in the schema, you can set additionalProperties to false.

OpenAPI Specification (OAS) v2 does not define this behavior, and the current tooling (such as parsers and codegen) does not support it. Instead, they only accept the value object for this property. OAS v2 does also support using additionalProperties to specify a schema to which the additional properties must conform.

Because boolean in additionalProperties is not a documented part of the OAS, the API implementation may not behave according to developer expectations. Such a discrepancy has an inherent risk and is not recommended.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-schema-additionalproperties-bool.shortDescription: The schema defines additionalProperties as a Boolean value.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this type of risk could look in your API definition. Here, additionalProperties is set to false. This behavior is supported in regular JSON but not in OAS v2:

code.yaml:
post:
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
          tag:
            type: string
        required:
          - name
        additionalProperties: false

sections.text:
Remediation

The safest option is not to allow additional properties. If the schema does not use allOf at all, make sure you define all properties of the accepted JSON payload in the schema itself.

Do not use combining operations (allOf) for defining additional properties in API definitions following the OAS v2.

We recommend updating your API definition to follow the OAS v3, because it offers proper support for additionalProperties as Boolean, in addition to other improvements.

If you cannot update your API to OAS v3, use additionalProperties to provide the schema that you want to support:

code.yaml:
post:
  operationId: addPet
  parameters:
    - name: pet
      in: body
      description: Pet to add to the store
      required: true
      schema:
        type: object
        properties:
          name:
            type: string
          tag:
            type: string
        required:
          - name
        additionalProperties:
          schema:
            $ref: "#/definitions/PetDetails"

title.text: Schema keyword used alongside enum

description.text:
Description

You have used a schema keyword alongside an enum. This is not allowed.

warning-schema-enum-property-improper.shortDescription: You have used a schema keyword alongside an enum. This is not allowed.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that schema properties that should not appear alongside enums do not do so.

title.text: Value of a schema example is not consistent with the schema

description.text:
Description

The example object you have defined is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

warning-schema-example-improper.shortDescription: The example object you have defined is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the example objects you define match the schemas of their associated values.

title.text: 'External Documentation' URL of the schema is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined the url field of the External Documentation object for the schema in question is not a proper URL.

You can use the externalDocs field to reference an external resource that offers extended documentation for your API. This is field is optional. However, if you do reference external documentation, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-schema-externaldocumentation-url.shortDescription: The URL defined the url field of the External Documentation object for the schema in question is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the url field has just a placeholder string:

code.yaml:
schema:
  type: string
  format: email
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: need to add later

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
schema:
  type: string
  format: email
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: http://my.api.com/docs/email

title.text: Schema format is not applicable to the schema's type

description.text:
Description

The format you have specified for a schema is not consistent with the type you have defined for the schema. While this is acceptable, it may not be what you want.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification and JSON Schema Validation.

warning-schema-format-improper.shortDescription: The format you have specified for a schema is not consistent with the type you have defined for the schema. While this is acceptable, it may not be what you want.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. The type of the schema is integer, but the format is float which is not an integer format:

code.yaml:
User:
  type: object
  properties:
    id:
      type: integer
      format: float

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that the formats of all schemas match the type of the schemas.

Numeric parameters type integer can have the format int32 or int64. Numeric parameters type number can have the format float or double.

code.yaml:
User:
  type: object
  properties:
    id:
      type: integer
      format: int32

title.text: Schema keyword is not applicable to the defined data type

description.text:
Description

The schema keyword you have defined is not applicable to the data type you have defined.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-schema-property-improper.shortDescription: The schema keyword you have defined is not applicable to the data type you have defined.

sections.text:
Remediation

title.text: Value of the 'x-42c-sample' extension is not consistent with the schema

description.text:

The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

warning-schema-sample-improper.shortDescription: The value of the extension x-42c-sample is not consistent with the schema of the associated value.

sections.text:

title.text: 'External Documentation' URL of the tag is not a proper URL

description.text:
Description

The URL defined the url field of the External Documentation object for a tag is not a proper URL.

You can use the externalDocs field to reference an external resource that offers extended documentation for your API. This is field is optional. However, if you do reference external documentation, the OpenAPI Specification (OAS) requires that all URLs in the API contract must be proper URLs in a valid format.

For more details, see the OpenAPI Specification.

warning-tag-externaldocumentation-url.shortDescription: The URL defined the url field of the External Documentation object for a tag is not a proper URL.

sections.text:
Example

The following is an example of how this issue could look in your API definition. Here, the url field has just a placeholder string:

code.yaml:
tag:
  name: pet
  description: Pet operations
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: need to add later

sections.text:
Remediation

Make sure that all URLs in your API are proper URLs and have a valid format.

code.yaml:
tag:
  name: pet
  description: Pet operations
  externalDocs:
    description: Find more info here
    url: http://petstore.api.com/docs/petsoperations
